Virus, Ahmaud Arbery, Solo Travel: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Democratic Convention Moves to Smaller Venue, as Delegates Are Urged to Stay Away
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic National Convention will move out of Milwaukees professional basketball arena, and state delegations are being urged not to travel to the city because of concerns about the coronavirus pandemic, party officials said Wednesday.

title: Tucson Police in Turmoil After Death of Latino Man in Custody
description: The police chief of Tucson, Ariz., abruptly offered to resign on Wednesday while releasing a video in which a 27-year-old Latino man, Carlos Ingram Lopez, died in police custody two months ago. Mayor Regina Romero on Thursday expressed confidence in the police chief, Chris Magnus, and said he would stay on the job.

title: U.S. Used Missile With Long Blades to Kill Qaeda Leader in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  American Special Operations forces used a specially designed secret missile to kill the head of a Qaeda affiliate in Syria this month, dealing the terrorist group a serious blow with a weapon that combines medieval brutality with advanced technology.

title: Trump Hosts Polish President in Oval Office
description: President Trump met with President Andrzej Duda of Poland in the Oval Office.

title: A Poet Whose Calling Is Doubt Celebrates Languages Uncertainty
description: MUDDY MATTERHORNPoems 2009-2019By Heather McHugh

title: A Winner on Election Day in November? Dont Count on It
description: The cliffhanger elections on Tuesday night in Kentucky and New York didnt just leave the candidates and voters in a state of suspended animation wondering who had won. Election officials, lawyers and political strategists in both parties said the lack of results was a bracing preview of what could come after the polls close in November: No clear and immediate winner in the presidential race.

title: Sergei Khrushchev, Son of Former Soviet Premier, Dies at 84
description: Sergei N. Khrushchev, a former Soviet rocket scientist and the son of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader during the Cold War of the 1950s and 60s, died on June 18 at his home in Cranston, R.I. He was 84.

title: Talladega Noose Incident Puts Spotlight on NASCARs Troubles With Racism
description: Darrell Wallace Jr. said he was relieved to hear the F.B.I. say he had not been the target of a hate crime at Talladega Superspeedway last weekend, after a noose hanging in his garage stall was found to have been there since at least last fall.

title: Trumps False Attacks on Voting by Mail Stir Broad Concern
description: President Trump is stepping up his attacks on the integrity of the election system, sowing doubts about the November vote at a time when the pandemic has upended normal balloting and as polls show former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. ahead by large margins.

title: Trump Is Feeding Americas Coronavirus Nightmare
description: President Trump says the coronavirus is fading away and pats himself on the back for a great job on CoronaVirus that saved millions of U.S. lives.

title: Trump, Out of Step
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Virus Cases Are Soaring in Texas. But Closing Down Again Is a Last Option.
description: HOUSTON  The coronavirus has been testing Americas governors. Few are being squeezed harder than Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas.

title: Breakthrough Drug for Covid-19 May Be Risky for Mild Cases
description: Scientists in Britain announced a major breakthrough in the battle against the coronavirus last week, reporting they had found the first drug to reduce deaths among critically ill Covid-19 patients.

title: Baseballs New Rules: No Spitting, No Arguing, and Lots of Testing
description: Coronavirus testing every other day for players and coaches. Wet rags for pitchers pockets to prevent them from licking their fingers. Masks in the dugout and bullpen for any non-players. And no public transportation to the stadium, communal food spreads, saunas, fighting, spitting, smokeless tobacco or sunflower seeds.

title: Tribe in South Dakota Seeks Court Ruling Over Standoff on Blocking Virus
description: WASHINGTON  Plagued with an inadequate health care system and fearful of what could happen if the coronavirus spread across its tribal lands in South Dakota, the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe took emergency steps 12 weeks ago, setting up checkpoints along roads into its reservation to question travelers about their health and their travel plans.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The U.S. recorded more than 35,000 new cases yesterday  the highest daily total since the outbreak first peaked in late April. More than half of all states saw increasing new cases, and governors across political lines moved to delay or reverse reopenings.

title: Coronavirus Surge Raises Alarm as States Report New Highs
description: On Wednesday, governors, mayors, investors and others across the United States woke up to news that was impossible to ignore. More than 35,000 new coronavirus cases had been identified the day before. It was the highest number reported in a single day since late April.

title: Michael Hawley, Programmer, Professor and Pianist, Dies at 58
description: Michael Hawley, a computer programmer, professor, musician, speechwriter and impresario who helped lay the intellectual groundwork for what is now called the Internet of Things, died on Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 58.

title: Trump Speaks! And Speaks. And Speaks
description: Donald Trump thinks were out to get him.

title: Corrections: June 25, 2020
description: An article on Wednesday about testimony before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the new surge in coronavirus cases misspelled the given name of one of the doctors testifying. He is Adm. Brett P. Giroir, not Brent.

title: Study Raises Concerns for Pregnant Women With the Coronavirus
description: Pregnant women infected with the coronavirus are more likely to be hospitalized, admitted to an intensive care unit and put on a ventilator than are infected women who are not pregnant, according to a new government analysis.

title: Quotation of the Day: United in Music, Faith and Messaging, Even After a Firing
description: Im a Catholic and a lesbian, an engineer and an artist, and a pacifist who works for the Army. I live in the middle of a paradox, so Ive always got one foot out the door, period.

title: Mississippi Man Charged With Threatening to Kill Congressman
description: A Mississippi man was charged in connection with a phone call threatening to kill a United States representative and his staffers, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: We Shall Overcome
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Many solvers ask how they are supposed to know when there is funny business going on in the grid. The short answer is to practice, so you will be exposed to a variety of puzzle tricks and learn to recognize them. Ive heard from a lot of solvers who dont seem to have the patience for that. They would like there to be a visible warning near the grid to tip them off.

title: Can We Call Trump a Killer?
description: The coronavirus pandemic is still raging in this country. In fact, in more than 20 states, the number of cases is rising. More than 120,000 Americans have died from the virus. This country has a quarter of all the cases in the world even though it makes up only 4 percent of the world population.

title: NASA Names Headquarters After Its First Black Female Engineer, Mary Jackson
description: NASA announced on Wednesday that it would name its Washington, D.C., headquarters after Mary Jackson, the organizations first black female engineer and a pivotal player in helping U.S. astronauts reach space.

title: Former Arizona Official Pleads Guilty in Adoption Scheme
description: A former elected official in Arizona who paid pregnant women as much as $10,000 to travel to the United States illegally to give up their newborn children for adoption pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a federal human smuggling conspiracy charge, the authorities said.

title: How the Virus Won
description: Invisible outbreaks sprang up everywhere. The United States ignored the warning signs. We reconstructed how the epidemic spun out of control.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: China is testing restaurant workers and delivery drivers block by block. South Korea tells people to carry two types of masks for different risky social situations. Britain is targeting local outbreaks in a strategy that Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls Whac-a-Mole.

title: For Those Getting Married, a Searchable Domestic Violence Database
description: A city in eastern China is preparing to roll out a database that would allow people getting married to check if their prospective partner has a history of domestic violence, in whats being called the first of its kind in the country.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Search Party and The Twilight Zone
description: SEARCH PARTY Stream on HBO Max. Could these hipsters be coldblooded murderers? That question is posed by a news anchor in a trailer for the new, third season of this dark comedy series. The show stars Alia Shawkat as Dory, a millennial who lives in Brooklyn. The first season followed her and a group of fellow Brooklynites investigating a disappearance; the second season involved a killing. After a couple years off, Dory and company are back, this time on HBOs new streaming service (the show was on TBS). Season 3 includes a high-stakes criminal trial, chic clothes and cynicism. Search Party, has always had a retro-tinged aesthetic, a slight thrift-store defect to its world, which makes it feel surreal at times  part of reality but not identical to it, Margaret Lyons wrote in a recent edition of The New York Timess Watching newsletter. Teasing out the contrast between the weightlessness of an imagined, curated past and the cruel density of the flawed, lived past is one of the shows most elegant tricks.

title: Hollywoods Comeback Stalls as Tenet Is Delayed Again
description: This briefing is no longer updating. The latest developments can be found here.

title: Late Night Celebrates Joe Bidens Joe-mentum
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: N.B.A. Ironmen Cling to Routine During the Load Management Era
description: Little will be ordinary when the abbreviated 2019-20 N.B.A. season resumes as expected on July 30. Games will be played at the Walt Disney World Resort inside a so-called bubble, a plan that does away with playoff basketballs normal hallmarks of rigorous travel, home-court advantage and the motivational fuel provided by screaming fans.

title: Trump Overhaul of Campus Sex Assault Rules Wins Surprising Support
description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos fired a shot last month in the nations culture wars, overhauling how colleges handle investigations of sexual assault and ending what she called Obama-era kangaroo courts on campus.

title: What We Know After the Primaries
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Judge John Hodgman on Having Several Pens in Your Pocket
description: Charlotte writes: My boyfriend carries three or four pens in his pants pockets at work. He still does this, even though were now working from home (in our 600-square-foot apartment). Today I found five pens in his pocket. Please order him to stop.

title: How the Philadelphia Police Tear-Gassed a Group of Trapped Protesters
description: On June 1, SWAT teams turned a protest march in Philadelphia into chaos. We went to the site, interviewed witnesses and analyzed dozens of videos to reconstruct what happened.

title: The Rebel Physicist on the Hunt for a Better Story Than Quantum Mechanics
description: The thing that amazes me is that quantum mechanics is only 100 years old, the physicist Angelo Bassi said. We were in conversation across a picnic table on a drab Soviet-era campus in Zagreb, an early-autumn breeze swishing through the yellowing leaves of some nearby trees. Its a baby, its nothing  100 years in the history of science. How can you just stop there? It doesnt make sense any way you look at it. We sat in the shadow of a rust-stained beige building where Bassi was about to speak at a workshop for physicists who specialize in the century-old subject.

title: Poem: Surveillance
description: Ganbatte is Japanese for hold out, persevere, do your best. In the spring of 2020, those concepts took on new meaning for everyone  as did the concept of donning a ski mask and jumping through any door. Sarah Kortemeiers poem from her mesmerizing debut collection, Ganbatte, offers a new twist on vigilance. Were being collected somewhere on video and in memory, at all times, and maybe we want to be. Balcony waves are not quite enough. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

title: Sarah Cooper Doesnt Mimic Trump. She Exposes Him.
description: When Sarah Cooper lip-syncs Donald Trumps news conferences, theres no lectern or presidential seal. Theres no Mike Pence, face calibrated to Placid Gratitude as he gazes beatifically into the middle distance, and no Dr. Anthony Fauci, looking as though hed give anything to be transported someplace better, like maybe Edvard Munchs The Scream. No, in Coopers version theres just Cooper, posting videos online, usually from her own apartment, miming along to the presidents characteristic rasp  part pontificating doorman, part tepid Marlon Brando impersonation, grasping from one excuse to another, one enemy to another, one wrecking ball to another.

title: Leo Tolstoy vs. the Police
description: In the early months of lockdown, many people stuck at home found themselves turning to unusual sources of comfort: Gov. Andrew Cuomos PowerPoint presentations, bread-baking (especially, for reasons unclear, sourdough) and War and Peace, Leo Tolstoys 1,200-page novel about the Napoleonic era in Russia.

title: Racing a World-Champion Rower in My Garage
description: On June 11th, my 38th birthday, I found myself head-to-head in a virtual rowing race against the 23-year-old rowing champion Oliver Zeidler. Me, a father of two who has been rowing in his garage for three years, against Olli. Ridiculous.

title: Want to Be in Stacey Abramss Book Club? Sorry, Its Family Only
description: WOMAN OF WORDS The last thing Stacey Abrams, who is a Democrat, wanted to do was write a memoir about losing the 2018 Georgia gubernatorial race to the Republican, Brian Kemp. She says the idea came up, but it was not appealing to me. As someone who has spent my adult life working on issues of access, justice and voting rights, I wanted to figure out, what could I say that was necessary? That told readers, heres what we have to know, so history doesnt repeat itself. I come from a family where our parents told us, if you see a problem, your job is to fix it. Writing is how I work through how to fix it.

title: A Governor on Her Own, With Everything at Stake
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Heading Up to Westchester for More Space at the Right Price. Which Home Would You Choose?
description: Tired of her grueling commute and tiny kitchen, a Manhattanite went north in search of a citified life in New Rochelle.

title: Pass-Fail Raises the Question: Whats the Point of Grades?
description: In the wake of the novel coronavirus pandemic, countless colleges and universities shifted from to A-F grades to a pass/fail system. As officials at Wellesley College explained, the general aim in doing so is to support one another without being required to make judgments.

title: Place Your Bets on Bidens V.P.
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

title: A Virus Walks Into a Bar
description: Everything you love about your neighborhood bar  the ambience, the crowds, the music, the free-flowing alcohol  makes it the ideal place to catch Covid-19.

title: Barrs Interest in Google Antitrust Case Keeps It Moving Swiftly
description: WASHINGTON  For months, lawyers at the Justice Department have been marshaling their forces for a possible antitrust lawsuit against Google, spurred on by the personal interest of Attorney General William P. Barr.

title: Are You Willing to Give Up Your Privilege?
description: I have lived on both sides of American inequality. I began life in the bottom 1 percent but found my way to the top. And I know, all too personally, that the distance between the two never has been greater.

title: Summers Here, and America Is Ready to Quarancheat
description: The first weekend in June, Cyr Olivia Coleman, 29, a student in Randolph, Mass., did something that even a month earlier would have felt like a far-fetched dream: took a family vacation.

title: Tammy Duckworth Is Battle Tested. Could She Help Joe Biden in His Biggest Mission?
description: Dan Milberg is a retired Army helicopter pilot who voted for Donald J. Trump in 2016, and does not wish to vote for him again. But before he can consider pulling the lever for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., he needs to know who his running mate will be.

title: Who Are the Key Voters Turning Against Trump?
description: Joe Biden may be ahead in national and many battleground polls, but Democrats are still fretting about whether key constituencies will turn out in November. In particular, they worry about the level of support from young black and Hispanic voters  for good reason.

title: Arizona Overwhelmed With Demand for Tests as U.S. System Shows Strain
description: People seeking drive-up coronavirus tests in Phoenix faced a three-mile-long car line last weekend. On Friday, Arizonas largest laboratory received twice as many samples as it could process. The phone line for testing appointments at a large site on the state fairgrounds now opens at 7 a.m. with 800 callers already in the queue.

title: The Pandemic Prevented Us From Photographing These Residents. So We Handed Them the Camera.
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: What Is Freedom? Teaching Kids Philosophy in a Pandemic
description: We dont really need going to school, Ella Wagar, a 10-year-old from Seattle, told her online peers during a recent Zoom session. What we really do need are friends. If you dont have friends, it sucks; you play alone, you eat alone.

title: Provocative Purchases? Surprisingly Thriving
description: When lockdown began a few months ago, as some women adopted sweatpants and worn-in tees as a virtual uniform, others were buying apparel thats considerably more alluring: lacy push-up bras, slinky thongs and other undergarments that are more characteristically reserved for P.P.E.-free, socially undistanced activities.

title: Hamilton Is Coming to the Small Screen. This Is How It Got There.
description: In the spring of 2017, a production executive withdrew an encrypted hard drive from a Midtown Manhattan vault and boarded a flight to London.

title: Books Are a Great Fit for Quarantine. The Book Business, Not So Much.
description: During a normal week, Jordan Pavlin, the editorial director at Knopf, seldom ate at her desk. Depending on the day, she might be meeting with literary agents over lunch, catching up with an author over an after-work drink, or having a quick bite before a cocktail party for a newly released title.

title: Coronavirus Is a Crisis. Might It Also Narrow Inequality?
description: The United States faces an economic downturn without precedent. Is it also a moment that could produce lasting change?

title: In Poll, Trump Falls Far Behind Biden in Six Key Battleground States
description: President Trump has lost significant ground in the six battleground states that clinched his Electoral College victory in 2016, according to New York Times/Siena College surveys, with Joseph R. Biden Jr. opening double-digit leads in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

title: The Black-White Wage Gap Is as Big as It Was in 1950
description: Thats remarkable. Despite decades of political change  the end of enforced segregation across the South, the legalization of interracial marriage, the passage of multiple civil rights laws and more  the wages of black men trail those of white men by as much as when Harry Truman was president. That gap indicates that there have also been powerful forces pushing against racial equality.

title: Road Tripping While Black: Readers Respond
description: The road trip has long been considered part of the great American experience, but the feeling of freedom often associated with getting in a car and seeing the country hasnt always been extended to African-American travelers, who often worry about discrimination and racism while traveling.

title: This College Football Team Had No Coronavirus Cases at First. Then It Shut Down.
description: When Kansas State opened the doors to its athletic facilities, welcoming its football players back to campus starting the first weekend in June, administrators breathed a sigh of relief once the first batch of coronavirus tests came back.

title: Trumps Sagging Popularity Drags Down Republican Senate Candidates
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps erratic performance in office and his deteriorating standing in the polls is posing a grave threat to his partys Senate majority, imperiling incumbents in crucial swing states and undermining Republican prospects in one of the few states they had hoped to gain a seat, according to a new poll of registered voters by The New York Times and Siena College.

title: When Bosses Shared Their Profits
description: After the bruising crises were now going through, it would be wonderful if we could somehow emerge a fairer nation. One possibility is to revive an old idea: sharing the profits.

title: Fireworks Conspiracy Theories: Why You Should Be Skeptical
description: When Anne-Marcelle Ngabirano first began hearing the fireworks at the end of May, she found them to be welcome sounds of celebration. But over the next few weeks, they sounded closer and closer to her three-bedroom apartment in Sunset Park, until the booms began rattling the walls and the apartment filled with smoke.

title: Bail Funds, Flush With Cash, Learn to Grind Through This Horrible Process
description: One afternoon in June, Elisabeth Epps hopped into her partners Jeep and rode from Denver to Boulder, carrying cashiers checks worth nearly $16,000.

title: When the Toppled Statue Is of Your Great-Great-Great-Grandfather
description: Clayton Wickham, 28, said he used to think of the statue of his great-great-great-grandfather as just a statue that had my name on it that was kind of cool to walk by every now and then.

title: How These Students Lost, and Recaptured, the Magic of Senior Year
description: No spring sports. No long-awaited trips abroad or senior spirit week. Proms delayed indefinitely, and graduations switched to Zoom.

title: A Coronavirus Care Package From China
description: CHICAGO  The motherland is by your side read the message printed on the plastic envelope. The characters were set in bright yellow against a crimson background, the same colors as on Chinas national flag. Genuine affection from 10,000 miles away.

title: Write a Book? Sure, Work From Home. Care for a Child? Nope.
description: Ever since the coronavirus pandemic began keeping most of us sheltered at home, work has rapidly shifted from the cubicle to the kitchen table. A number of surveys indicate that about half of the American work force is now doing their work at home. Companies that may have once been resistant to letting employees off the in-person leash are finding that yes, work can still get done outside the confines of an office building.

title: Some of Frances Only Live Theater Right Now Is a Historical Affront
description: LES EPESSES, France  While most French theaters remain closed and live sports wont resume until July, there is one arena in the country where thousands can already sit down to watch a show. In a Roman-style amphitheater at the Puy du Fou, a historical theme park in western France, gladiators in period costumes have been performing daily since June 11.

title: As New Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record in the U.S., Some States Delay Reopenings
description: The United States on Thursday reported more than 41,000 new coronavirus cases, a record  total for the second straight day, as a nationwide sense of urgency grew and caseloads soared in Southern and Western states that were far removed from the worst early outbreaks.

title: The Ending of This Louisa May Alcott Story May Disappoint You
description: A previously unpublished piece by Louisa May Alcott, the author best known for her novel Little Women, is now available in print for the first time.

title: Momentum for an Effort to Save Children From Sweltering Cars
description: There was reason for optimism last June. The Hot Cars Act of 2019 appeared to be making some progress. The bill would require a device that could warn drivers and car owners of a child left behind in a car or one who had gotten into a parked car.

title: The Voters Trump Is Losing
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Wirecard, Reeling From Accounting Scandal, Files for Insolvency
description: Wirecard, the troubled German company that became embroiled in a scandal over a missing $2.1 billion, said on Thursday that it would file for insolvency.

title: The Enormous Black-White Wage Gap
description: One remarkable sign of the racial inequities plaguing the United States: The wage gap between black and white men is as large today as it was in 1950.

title: We Are Definitely Not Out of the Woods
description: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

title: The Audition Review: A Violin Teacher on the Verge
description: This picture kicks off with a scene we may think weve seen many times: a tryout at a prestigious music school. A group of exacting adults assesses a series of young classical players; we may think the aspiring ones sound OK or better, but the grown-ups are brutal. Its their job to be, and their ears are trained to be.

title: Ella Fitzgerald: Just One of Those Things Review: Words Without Much Music
description: Ella Fitzgerald: Just One of Those Things salutes the singer who became known as the first lady of song  whose six-decade career stretched from the comforts of novelty tunes to the cutting edge of jazz  with a PBS-ready treatment. It proceeds dryly and largely chronologically through her life, sometimes with an awkward sense of proportion. (Is it necessary for a full closing title card to note that Fitzgerald, who died in 1996, had both legs amputated toward the end of her life?)

title: All I Can Say Review: A Rock Star Captures His Own Rise and Fall
description: The musician Shannon Hoon, who died in 1995 of complications from a drug overdose at the age of 28, was an inveterate self-chronicler. The documentary All I Can Say credits Hoon as one of four directors and was assembled from video footage he recorded from 1990 until mere hours before his death. It chronicles, among other things, the rise and decline of his band Blind Melon.

title: The 11th Green Review: Investigating Aliens, Eisenhower and Golf
description: Christopher Munch has a near-unique filmmaking voice, possessed of an understatement that can register either as droll or profound, and sometimes as both. He doesnt get to exercise that voice too frequently, alas.

title: U.S.T.A. Reinstates U.S. Open Wheelchair Tournament
description: After an outcry from players, the United States Tennis Association has restored the wheelchair tennis competition to the 2020 United States Open.

title: A Full View, at Last, of Modern Art in South Korea
description: Many rich nations use art, music and movies to project an image to the world, but few take it as seriously as South Korea  todays uncontested champion of cultural soft power. In the last 20 years, the nations singers and actors have thumped to Asian and then worldwide superstardom  signaled in 2012 by the viral amusement Gangnam Style (the first song to hit a billion views on YouTube); strengthened by the stadium-filling concerts of BTS, Loona and other K-pop bands; and capped recently by the unprecedented best picture Oscar for Bong Joon Hos Parasite.

title: Roddy Doyle Scored 8 Out of 10 on a Quiz About Roddy Doyle
description: What books are on your nightstand?

title: Bombshell Testimony Against Trump and Barr
description: Damning testimony and election warnings. Its Thursday, and this is your tip sheet.

title: In Vintage TV Ads, a Curious Fountain of Hope (and Cheese)
description: At the end of yet another long day indoors, when I want to unwind, Ill put on the commercial breaks from the 1985 American Music Awards or CBSs May 3, 1983, broadcast of The Hunchback of Notre Dame. I am transported to a magical time, full of smiling faces and hokey jingles, when you could buy a new car for less than $10,000 and Kraft had a line of Casino cheeses that were extra mild, in case regular Kraft cheese was too flavorful for you.

title: Congos Deadliest Ebola Outbreak Is Declared Over
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The second-worst Ebola outbreak in history is over, the World Health Organization said on Thursday, after nearly two years and 2,280 deaths.

title: Beats Review: A Last Hurrah, and a First Trip
description: Like the party that serves as its climax, the retro teenage-friendship movie Beats, set in 1994 in Scotland, owes its appeal to mood and vibe. The soundtrack provides a constant, toe-tapping thump.

title: 22 Police Officers Injured in Scuffles at Illegal London Block Party
description: At least 22 police officers were injured in South London on Wednesday night as they tried to disperse crowds that had gathered for an illegal outdoor party in defiance of coronavirus restrictions, the police said.

title: How an Oakland Bar Is Preparing to Reopen
description: Good morning.

title: With Unemployment Offices Busy, Recovery Seems a Long Haul
description: As American businesses reopen in fits and starts  and anxiety over new coronavirus hot spots increases  state unemployment offices still have their hands full.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: More Adults Than Ever Live With Parents or Grandparents
description: A record 32 million American adults were living with their parents or grandparents in April, according to the Current Population Survey from the U.S. Census Bureau, an increase of 9.7 percent over a year ago. The data, analyzed by Zillow researchers, showed that 2.7 million adults moved back home in March and April, and that about 2.2 million of them were aged 18 to 25  also known as Generation Z.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Prospect Heights, Forest Hills and the Sutton Place neighborhood.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a six-bedroom in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: When the Louvre Reopens, Its Going to Be Quiet
description: The Muse du Louvre in Paris is set to reopen on July 6 after a 16-week shutdown that has taken a 40-million-euro toll on its bottom line.

title: New Rule in California Will Require Zero-Emissions Trucks
description: Rebuffing strong opposition from industry, California on Thursday adopted a landmark rule requiring more than half of all trucks sold in the state to be zero-emissions by 2035, a move that is expected to improve local air quality, rein in greenhouse gas emissions and sharply curtail the states dependence on oil.

title: Is It Safe to Go Back to the Dentist?
description: At Dr. Todd Bertmans office, the receptionist wears a plastic face shield. So do the hygienist and the nine doctors in the practice in Manhattans East Village.

title: My Spy Review: A Secret Agent Gets Outsmarted
description: In the kind of movie My Spy is, comedy is derived from fish-out-of-water scenarios. The flailing fish here is the burly, physically adept C.I.A. field agent JJ (Dave Bautista), who is demoted and left gallivanting around the schoolyard with the 9-year-old girl, Sophie (Chloe Coleman). The plan is to nab Sophies nefarious uncle, Marquez (Greg Bryk), who is on the brink of selling nuclear weapons plans to another terrorist. There are pratfalls and dodge ball along the way.

title: $1 Billion in Government Coronavirus Payments Went to Dead People
description: Congresss watchdog on Thursday criticized the federal governments response to the coronavirus pandemic, noting that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is inaccurately counting coronavirus tests and that more than $1 billion in payments had been issued to dead people.

title: The Last Days of Pop Smoke
description: Every so often, though far less frequently than it used to, New York hip-hop mints an ambassador, someone whos faithful to the grit of the citys musical legacy while possessing the charisma to transcend it.

title: Gone With the Wind Returns to HBO Max With a Few Additions
description: When HBO Max removed the Oscar-winning 1939 adaptation of Margaret Mitchells Gone With the Wind from its streaming catalog earlier this month, the service promised that the film would return, albeit with a discussion of its historical context. On Wednesday, the film quietly resumed its place in that library, and the streamer made good on its promise with two noteworthy additions.

title: Supreme Court Says Rejected Asylum Seekers Have No Right to Object in Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court sided on Thursday with the Trump administrations efforts to speed the deportation of asylum seekers, ruling that a law limiting the role of federal courts in reviewing those decisions was constitutional.

title: What Will Happen With Weddings?
description: Coronavirus or not, one thing is certain: People will find each other, they will fall in love, and somehow, they will say their vows.

title: How to Handle a Mom-Friend Breakup
description: L and I connected online, as pregnant women sometimes do. I began reading her blog, and she mine. We met at a downtown caf, where we shared a waffle with ice cream, a few weeks after exchanging our first emails. During our pregnancies, we went to the same prenatal education classes  birthing, breastfeeding, infant first aid. We swapped yoga and baby-wearing and infant-clothing resources.

title: Three N.C. Officers Fired After Police Find Racist Comments on Video
description: Three police officers in Wilmington, N.C., were fired after a supervisor found recorded conversations that included racist remarks, slurs and one officer saying he cant wait to start slaughtering black people, the department announced Wednesday.

title: Kentucky Derby to Allow Spectators in September
description: The Kentucky Derby  known for its atmosphere as much as its thoroughbred racing  is keeping its fans this year for betting, mint juleps, and to see and be seen with elaborate millinery and seersucker suits.

title: 3 Long (Haired) Months: Barbershop Before-and-Afters
description: For the last three months, Ive spent my Google Hangout work meetings wearing a Yankees cap. Despite being a born-and-bred New Yorker, I am not a Yankees fan at all. But it was the only cap I had in my house to cover my lack of a shape-up, my lack of a haircut, with barbershops in the city closed because of the pandemic.

title: The Last Tree Review: Struggles of a New Life
description: The Last Tree, the visually arresting second feature from Shola Amoo, offers a coming-of-age narrative guided by fluid definitions of family, strains of cultural tension and the quest for personal freedom.

title: Dog Breeding in the Neolithic Age
description: There are two broad stories about dogs and humans. One is of a deep and meaningful partnership between two species that ensures the survival of both. The other is of scavengers and camp followers that live off our garbage and feed on our corpses in the shadow of war.

title: When 300-Pound Wombats Roamed Australia
description: Wombats and koalas stand out as bizarre animals even in a continent famed for bizarre animals. They are also each others closest relatives.

title: Dolphins Have an Eating Trick. How They Learn It Is More Surprising.
description: When hunger strikes, dolphins dont mess around.

title: Pandemics Cleaner Air Could Reshape What We Know About the Atmosphere
description: WASHINGTON  In the crystalline air of the pandemic economy, climate change researchers have been flying a small plane over Route I-95, from Boston to Washington, measuring carbon dioxide levels. Scientists have mounted air quality monitors on Salt Lake Citys light rail system to create intersection-by-intersection atmospheric profiles.

title: Two Black Holes Colliding Not Enough? Make It Three
description: In an announcement on Thursday, astronomers described the detection of an epistemological marvel: an invisible collision of invisible objects  black holes  had become briefly visible. The story goes like this:

title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Charged With Using Illegal Chokehold
description: A New York City police officer was arrested on Thursday morning and charged with illegally using a chokehold to subdue a man on the boardwalk at a Queens beach, becoming the first city officer to be charged under a new state law making it a felony for the police to use such holds.

title: The Dixie Chicks Change Their Name, Dropping the Dixie
description: The Dixie Chicks are now the Chicks.

title: Dennis Nagle, Free Spirit With an Engineers Mind, Dies at 78
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Tips for Making Your Mask Work
description: Wearing masks can protect you and those around you, but they can come with frustrations. Here are some tips on making them work better for you.

title: Australia and New Zealand Will Host 2023 Womens World Cup
description: Australia and New Zealand will serve as co-hosts for the 2023 Womens World Cup, FIFA announced Thursday, sending one of its two biggest tournaments  and its first 32-team womens championship  to two nations that have embraced the womens game.

title: Israel Announces Partnership With U.A.E., Which Throws Cold Water On It
description: TEL AVIV, Israel  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced a new partnership with the United Arab Emirates on Thursday to cooperate in the fight against the coronavirus, portraying it as the latest advance in the Jewish states efforts to build stronger ties with Arab states.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: School by Zoom might have been weird and compromised and unsatisfying, true. But now that its over and summer looms menacingly ahead with nothing but question marks for parents and kids  Is camp really safe? What about a job at the local mall or movie theater? What are we supposed to doooooo all day?  books are here to help. (Books are always here to help.) For the teens and tweens in my house, distraction has come lately by way of Jonathan Waldman and Rainbow Rowell and Pam Muoz Ryan; for the parents and kids together, its come by way of nightly read-alouds from Philip Pullmans His Dark Materials trilogy.

title: 8 Things to Do This Weekend
description: In recent years, at least two major Pride events in New York could be described as part dance party, part arts happening: Everybooty at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the House Party at New York Live Arts. This year, when both organizations had to figure out how to celebrate community in a time of social distancing, they decided to make a bigger noise by going online together.

title: Defense Secretary Faces White House Pressure on Aides and a Military Promotion
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is facing a hemorrhage of talent as senior officials resign amid continued efforts by the White House to purge those perceived as political foes, including the Army lieutenant colonel who testified in the House impeachment hearings.

title: Every Work of American Literature Is About Race: Writers on How We Got Here
description: Almost 100 years ago, responding to the public outcry over the violent drowning of a Black boy by a white mob at a public beach on Lake Michigan, a citywide (multiracial but white-led) commission published The Negro in Chicago: A Study of Race Relations and a Race Riot.

title: Madison Cawthorn Wants to Defuse the G.O.P.s Generational Time Bomb
description: If all goes according to plan, Madison Cawthorn, 24, will be the next representative from North Carolinas 11th Congressional District. He will turn 25, the minimum age to serve in the House, just a few months before the election.

title: Chris Trousdale, Boy Band Idol With a Broadway Past, Dies at 34
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Viewing Party! Lets all Watch Jurassic Park
description: What is summer without summer blockbusters? Movie-craving Americans are about to find out. Yes, some theaters are making cautious plans to reopen next month  well see how that goes  but for the first time in forever, were facing a Fourth of July weekend without a big popcorn spectacle to provide thrills, laughs, groans, action and air-conditioning. In place of such delights, we decided for our next Weekend Watch to revisit a commercial juggernaut from the past with the hungry dinosaurs and terrified humans of Jurassic Park.

title: When the Police Treat Software Like Magic
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Irresistible Review: The Voters Are Red, the Message Is Blue
description: East Coast slickness meets heartland folksiness in Irresistible, a political satire so broad and blunt that it flattens every joke and deflates every setup. Movies like this should skip and jab; instead, this second feature from the writer and director Jon Stewart (after his impressively accomplished prison drama, Rosewater, in 2014) lumbers and flails. Set shortly after the 2016 election, it feels like an artifact from a particularly contentious past, a stale corn chip trampled into Party-convention carpeting.

title: A Penny for Your Thoughts Could Be a Lot Harder to Find
description: WASHINGTON  Randy Graham, the chief executive of the First National Bank of Tennessee, was surprised to learn in mid-June that the Federal Reserve would not be filling his entire order of pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters.

title: A Regular Woman Review: A Family Murder, as Told by the Victim
description: The drama A Regular Woman depicts the true story of Hatun Surucu  known to her friends as Aynur  a German woman of Turkish-Kurdish descent who was shot and killed by her brother in 2005. (The brother who pulled the trigger pleaded guilty in German courts, while two different brothers were recently acquitted of the crime, a so-called honor killing that made international news and inspired an earlier 2011 film.)

title: Trump Administration May End Congressional Review of Foreign Arms Sales
description: Senior Trump administration officials are quietly discussing whether to end a decades-old process for congressional review that has allowed lawmakers from both parties to block weapons sales to foreign governments over humanitarian concerns, according to current and former administration officials and congressional aides. The move could quickly advance sales of bombs to Saudi Arabia, among other deals.

title: Devin Nunes Cant Sue Twitter Over Cow and Mom Parodies, Judge Says
description: A Virginia judge said this week that Representative Devin Nunes could not sue Twitter over posts by two parody accounts and a Republican strategist, ruling that a federal communications law protects the social media company from being held liable for the posts.

title: Review: A Killer, a Writer, and the Questions Both Left Behind
description: True-crime fans who come to the HBO documentary Ill Be Gone in the Dark should know in advance that it is not, strictly speaking, a true-crime series about the decades-long hunt for the serial rapist and murderer known as the Golden State Killer.

title: $1.4 Billion in Stimulus Funds Sent to Dead People, Watchdog Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration delivered more than a million stimulus payments worth about $1.4 billion to dead people in a rush to pump money into the economy this year, the Government Accountability Office said on Thursday.

title: Berkeley Art Museum Names a New Director
description: The University of California Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive announced on Thursday that Julie Rodrigues Widholm will succeed Lawrence Rinder as the institutions director and chief curator. Her appointment comes at a time when museums across the country are trying to chart a path forward amid an ongoing global health crisis and simmering social unrest.

title: Labours New Leader Fires Official Over Charges of Anti-Semitism
description: LONDON  In a decisive break with the hard-left wing of Britains opposition Labour Party, its new leader dismissed a senior lawmaker on his leadership team Thursday for having shared an article online that the party said contained an anti-Semitic conspiracy theory.

title: Jenny Slate and Kristen Bell Leave Voice Roles as Black Characters
description: Two white actresses who voiced black characters on popular animated television shows announced that they would step down on Wednesday, extending a season of soul searching over systemic racism that has touched multiple industries in the wake of recent police killings of African-Americans.

title: E.U. Barring U.S. Visitors a Huge Deal for Airlines
description: Delta Air Lines was hoping to restart flights next month from New York to Athens and Lisbon, two popular summer destinations, but it will probably have to wait a little longer.

title: Behind the Cover: What Is Owed
Dr. Robert Gallo: The Case for a Stopgap Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Cinma Vrit Exist? Watch These 2 Movies to Find Out
description: For a genre that ostensibly presents snippets of unvarnished truth, a particular type of documentary is difficult to name. The opening of Chronicle of a Summer (1961), a groundbreaking example by the anthropologist Jean Rouch and the sociologist Edgar Morin, calls it cinma vrit. To the brothers Albert and David Maysles, it was direct cinema. Frederick Wiseman has used the phrase reality fictions. But in a 2015 interview, he told me he meant that term in jest: If Truman Capote could describe In Cold Blood as a nonfiction novel, then surely Wiseman could say his own films  shot unobtrusively, then edited with an eye toward characterization  added a novelistic spin to reality.

title: Five Nonbinary Comics on This Moment: Im Not Some New Buzzword
description: The stand-up comedian Jes Tom has a go-to pronoun joke: I like when people call me they. It makes me feel less lonely.

title: Elsa Joubert, 97, Dies; Afrikaans Writer Explored Black Reality
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Lightning and Violent Rainstorms Kill Scores in India
description: NEW DELHI   Scores of people died in violent rainstorms in northeastern India on Thursday, including many farmers working in their fields and children playing outside who were killed by lightning strikes, Indian officials said.The storms came as the yearly monsoon rains began in northern India, sweeping across the subcontinent and drenching cities and towns in their path.Natures fury was at its worst today, said Manoj Kumar Tiwary, a top police official in the state of Bihar, which reported on its Facebook page that 83 people had died of lightning strikes across the state. Officials also reported widespread damage to property across the state.

title: Theater Streams Make Room for Molire (and Imelda Marcos)
description: In the BC era (Before Covid-19), theater lovers tended to eye screens warily. Now, we browse the Broadway HD catalog, scout YouTube for obscure European webcasts and text each other the link to Lin-Manuel Mirandas 14-minute musical 21 Chump Street.

title: U.S. Postpones Balkan Peace Summit, in Blow to Trump Foreign Policy
description: BERLIN  An American-mediated initiative to stabilize the Balkans, which the Trump administration hoped might burnish its foreign policy credentials in an election year, was postponed on Thursday after one of the main participants, President Hashim Thaci of Kosovo, was indicted on war crimes charges.

title: When Facebook Politics Get Extra Personal
description: As the presidential election draws near, I would like to like to post a message on my Facebook timeline that says: If any of my Facebook friends plan on voting for a particular candidate, I would appreciate your doing me the courtesy of unfriending me. I no longer want to be associated with people who share a worldview, political views or, most important, the same set of morals as this candidate. They are completely antithetical to mine. My husband thinks I should not make this post. You?

title: Youre Probably Inhaling Microplastics Right Now
description: LOGAN, Utah  We werent looking for what we found.

title: A Suicide, an App and a Time for a Reckoning
description: I spent a lot of time this week trying to come up with the best way to get those who make things in Silicon Valley to better understand the suicide of Alex Kearns, a student at the University of Nebraska. He killed himself after he mistakenly believed that he had a $730,000 negative balance on the millennial-popular Robinhood app, which he had downloaded to learn about investing.

title: Photographing the Beauty of My Mothers Decline
description: DURHAM, N.H.  My mother has vascular dementia. Her brain, damaged from a slow decline in circulation, has left her with memory loss.

title: Bans and Quarantines for Travelers to New York and the E.U.
description: To the Editor:

title: We Know How George Floyd Died. It Wasnt From Drugs.
description: My heart sank when I read the prosecutors criminal complaint against Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who is charged with killing George Floyd. It suggests that drugs were one factor contributing to his death.

title: Jay Clayton, Would-Be Prosecutor, Says Hes Focused on His Current Job
description: Jay Clayton is not withdrawing his nomination as the next federal prosecutor in Manhattan, but he doesnt plan to give up his day job as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission anytime soon.

title: Addressing Diversity, Army Will Remove Photos of Officer Candidates in Promotion Reviews
description: WASHINGTON  The Army will remove photographs of candidates in promotion board hearings, senior officials said on Thursday, as part of an effort to address why so many black officers are being passed over in favor of their white counterparts.

title: Flare-Up in Virus Cases Sets Back Germanys Efforts to Reopen
description: BERLIN  A spike of more than 1,500 coronavirus infections within days has dealt a sudden blow to Germanys efforts to reopen the country, calling into question the durability of what had been widely considered a success story in managing the contagion in Europe.

title: James Browns Will: Is It Inching Toward Closure After 14 Years?
description: After more than a decade of litigation over James Browns estate, which he, the Godfather of Soul, had largely bequeathed to underprivileged students in South Carolina and Georgia, the chief justice of South Carolinas Supreme Court seemed irritated.

title: U.S. Virus Surge, China Database, Womens World Cup: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Akbar Nurid-Din Shabazz, Texas Prison Chaplain, Dies at 70
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Fed Limits Bank Payouts and Suspends Share Buybacks as Pandemic Grinds On
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve on Thursday temporarily restricted shareholder payouts by the nations biggest banks, barring them from buying back their own stocks or increasing dividend payments in the third quarter as regulators try to ensure banks remain strong enough to keep lending through the pandemic-induced downturn.

title: Biden Hits Trumps Coronavirus Response: Hes Worried About Looking Bad
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday laced into President Trump, condemning him for saying he had ordered a slowdown of coronavirus testing and comparing the sitting president to a whiny child.

title: A Historic Heat Wave Roasts Siberia
description: MOSCOW  They used to ride snowmobiles in June in Russkoye Ustye, a Siberian village by the Arctic Ocean coast.

title: Zeev Sternhell, Super Zionist Wary of Extremism, Dies at 85
description: Zeev Sternhell, a Holocaust survivor and an expert in 20th-century European fascism and the kind of extreme nationalism that he viewed as a threat to democracy in Israel, died on June 21 in Jerusalem. He was 85.

title: Disneys Splash Mountain to Drop Song of the South Depictions
description: LOS ANGELES  So long, Splash Mountain.

title: Germany Sees a Spike in Coronavirus Cases
description: A flare-up in Germany has led to more than 1,500 new infections concentrated in slaughterhouses and crowded, low-income apartment blocks.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

title: John J. Mooney, an Inventor of the Catalytic Converter, Dies at 90
description: John J. Mooney, an inventor of the catalytic converter, the small and ubiquitous device that makes the engines that power everything from cars to lawn mowers less polluting and more fuel efficient, died on June 16 at his home in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 90.

title: Senate Panel Moves to Empower Justice Dept. Watchdog Over Barrs Objections
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican-controlled Senate on Thursday advanced an effort to expand the power of the Justice Departments independent watchdog to investigate allegations of ethical violations and professional misconduct by department lawyers, overriding the objections of Attorney General William P. Barr.

title: Still Reeling From Oil Plunge, Texas Faces New Threat: Surge in Virus Cases
description: HOUSTON  Things were looking up for Texas in recent weeks. Oil prices had managed an impressive rebound, more than doubling to just above $40 a barrel. Restaurants and small businesses were opening up in Houston, Dallas and elsewhere. And tens of thousands of people were getting back to work.

title: Disgraced Lobbyist Jack Abramoff Headed Back to Jail
description: Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist whose corruption became a symbol of the excesses of Washington influence peddling, is set to return to jail for violating the law that was amended in response to his earlier crimes, law enforcement officials said on Thursday.

title: In Norway, Gymgoers Avoid Infections as Virus Recedes
description: Like many countries, Norway ordered all gyms to close in March to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. But unlike any other nation, Norway also funded a rigorous study to determine whether the closings were really necessary.

title: N.F.L. Trims Early Preseason Game and Prepares for Training Camps
description: The N.F.L. on Thursday canceled its annual Hall of Fame Game, an exhibition scheduled for Aug. 6, so players and coaches grappling with restrictions related to the coronavirus pandemic could have more time to prepare for the regular season, which, for now, is still set to begin Sept. 10.

title: Trump Family Will Ask Second Court to Stop Publication of Tell-All Book
description: A Queens County, N.Y., Surrogates Court judge on Thursday rejected a request to bar President Trumps niece, Mary L. Trump, from publishing a tell-all book about the family because the court lacked jurisdiction in the case.

title: I Humbly Apologize: Philadelphia Officials Announce Changes After Protest Response
description: Officials in Philadelphia on Thursday announced a moratorium on the use of tear gas in the city and apologized for their response to a June 1 protest against police brutality.

title: America Didnt Give Up on Covid-19. Republicans Did.
description: Earlier this year much of America went through hell as the nation struggled to deal with Covid-19. More than 120,000 Americans have now died; more than 20 million have lost their jobs.

title: Heres What You Need to Know About Elijah McClains Death
description: As outrage over police brutality has erupted across the country in the wake of George Floyds death, a wave of fresh attention and scrutiny has been applied to older cases in which people died after encounters with the police.

title: The Theater Where Ella Fitzgerald Got Her Start
description: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

title: Winners of Our Third Annual Podcast Contest
description: A personal conversation between a daughter and her deceased father, who had died by suicide. A one-act play written and performed by teenagers, via Zoom. A first-person account by a student sharing what it was like to experience homelessness.

title: What Is to Be Done About American Policing?
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

title: Inside Barrs Effort to Undermine Prosecutors in N.Y.
description: Shortly after he became attorney general last year, William P. Barr set out to challenge a signature criminal case that touched President Trumps inner circle directly, and even the presidents own actions: the prosecution of Michael D. Cohen, Mr. Trumps longtime fixer.

title: Texas, Unemployment, Hamilton: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trump Needs to Stop Caring About How He Looks: Biden Criticizes Presidents Virus Response
description: The former vice president called President Trumps response to the pandemic self-centered and compared him to a child.

title: Black Lives Matter Will Be Painted on Street Outside Trump Tower
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has ignited a new feud with President Trump by ordering the words Black Lives Matter to be painted in large yellow letters on the street outside of Trump Tower.

title: Texas Pauses Reopening as Virus Cases Soar Across the South and West
description: HOUSTON  Just 55 days after reopening Texas restaurants and other businesses, Gov. Greg Abbott on Thursday hit the pause button, stopping additional phases of the states reopening as new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations soared and as the governor struggled to pull off the seemingly impossible task of keeping both the state open and the virus under control.

title: Free Produce, With a Side of Shaming
description: Once a week, a blocklong line of men and women in surgical masks stretches down Neptune Avenue in Coney Island. Their goal is a food pantry that has cardboard containers stacked on the sidewalk in front.

title: Its a Pandemic, Stupid
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Police Groups Wield Strong Influence in Congress, Resisting the Strictest Reforms
description: WASHINGTON  As Americans were clamoring in the streets last week to defund the police and as Democrats in Congress were drafting legislation to make it easier to track and prosecute officer misconduct, Larry Cosme, a leader of the police lobby, was at the White House making a direct appeal to some of President Trumps top advisers against some of the most consequential reforms.

title: Russian Criminal Group Finds New Target: Americans Working at Home
description: A Russian ransomware group whose leaders were indicted by the Justice Department in December is retaliating against the U.S. government, many of Americas largest companies and a major news organization, identifying employees working from home during the pandemic and attempting to get inside their networks with malware intended to cripple their operations.

title: Philadelphia Police Temporarily Ban Tear Gas for Crowd Control
description: The announcement came hours after The New York Times published its visual investigation into a protest against police brutality in Philadelphia on June 1.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: As the United States records more daily infections than ever before, it is confronting a perilous new stage in the outbreak, with the resurgence largely concentrated in the South and the West. Heres a look at whats happening in a few of the countrys hot spots.

title: Five Months After Celebrating the Economy in Wisconsin, Trump Returns to a Different Place
description: Five months ago, President Trump fired up thousands of fans at a campaign rally in Milwaukee with a boastful question for a state he barely won in 2016: How are your 401(k)s doing? he bellowed.

title: Huge Explosion Near Irans Chief Military Base Shakes Residents
description: A huge explosion in the area of a major Iranian military and weapons development base east of Tehran turned the skyline bright orange for several seconds early Friday morning, official news agencies reported.

title: Another Nightmare Video and the Police on the Defensive in Tucson
description: It was another gruesome video of policing in America  a naked Latino man, his face covered by a mesh spit guard, his hands cuffed behind him as he lay dying face down on the ground at his grandmothers house. He pleaded for water more than a dozen times, saying he could not breathe as police officers restrained his legs and torso.

title: America Is Facing 5 Epic Crises All at Once
description: There are five gigantic changes happening in America right now. The first is that we are losing the fight against Covid-19. Our behavior doesnt have anything to do with the reality around us. We just got tired so were giving up.

title: The Coronavirus Crisis Inside Prisons Wont Stay Behind Bars
description: The situation inside the nations jails and prisons amid the Covid-19 pandemic has become the stuff of nightmares. Overcrowding, unsanitary conditions, shortages of personal protective equipment (not to mention soap) and restrictions on hygiene products such as hand sanitizer have turned detention facilities into a playground for the virus and a death trap for inmates  many of whom, because of age or pre-existing conditions, are at elevated risk for complications. And the threat extends far beyond the facilities themselves, endangering the families and communities that surround prison guards, nurses and other staff members.

title: Trump Praises Navy Contract at Wisconsin Shipyard
description: President Trump returned to Wisconsin on Thursday and boasted about the economic benefits of a Navy contract at a shipyard on Lake Michigan.

title: As Virus Surges, Younger People Account for Disturbing Number of Cases
description: CHICAGO  Younger people are making up a growing percentage of new coronavirus cases in cities and states where the virus is now surging, a trend that has alarmed public health officials and prompted renewed pleas for masks and social distancing.

title: House Passes Sweeping Policing Bill Targeting Racial Bias and Use of Force
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday passed an expansive policing overhaul bill aimed at combating racial discrimination and excessive use of force in law enforcement, as Democrats sought to respond to a nationwide outcry for racial justice and pushed through legislation that is doomed in the Republican-controlled Senate.

title: Liverpool Wins Premier League Without Breaking a Sweat
description: LIVERPOOL, England  The first fireworks burst into the clear, still sky a few minutes early, a thud, a fizz and a crackle of what was to come. It had not happened  not quite, not yet  but after 30 long years, a little impatience was understandable.

title: Criticism of Skin Lighteners Brings Retreat by Unilever and Johnson & Johnson
description: As major consumer products companies have rushed to declare their opposition to racism in response to the national outrage over the killing of George Floyd, many of them have been accused of openly promoting a beauty standard rooted in racism and discrimination.

title: Taking the High Road
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  The New York Times Crossword appears online the evening before its publication date, and I am often asked by readers why that is. The short answer is that, when it was originally offered online, the release of the Crossword was intended to match the time that the first edition of the print paper came out, which was at 10 p.m. Eastern. These days, parts of the print edition are published at different times, but the release of the online Crossword has remained the same.

title: Quotation of the Day: As Fireworks Light Up City, Skeptics Seek True Meaning
description: The past few weeks its been like the day before the 4th of July every day. We cant keep our shelves stocked.

title: Corrections: June 26, 2020
description: An article on Thursday about the indictment of the President Hashim Thaci of Kosovo for war crimes committed during Kosovos battle for independence from Serbia misstated the year that the Kosovar Parliament founded a special judicial system to investigate possible war crimes carried out by guerrilla groups. It was 2015, not 2016.

title: Li Zhensheng, Photographer of Chinas Cultural Revolution, Dies at 79
description: Li Zhensheng, a photographer who at great personal risk documented the dark side of Mao Zedongs Cultural Revolution, producing powerful black-and-white images that remain a rare visual testament to the brutality of that tumultuous period, many of them not developed or seen for years, has died. He was 79.

title: As He Cut My Hair, I Wept
description: A few weeks ago, I gave myself a crew cut. I didnt know how long it would be before I could visit a barber and figured I might as well do it myself.

title: Coronavirus Resurgence, Germany, FIFA: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Friday: Home Game and Irresistible
description: HOME GAME Stream on Netflix. See athletes risk their lives on several continents  and at sea  in this documentary series, which looks at traditional sports around the globe. These include calcio storico, a centuries-old competition in Florence, Italy, that at once resembles football, rugby and street fighting; kok-boru, a game played in Kyrgyzstan that involves competitors on horseback throwing a goat carcass into a goal; and free diving  in which divers plunge into the ocean without oxygen tanks  in the Philippines. The seriess eight episodes each explore a different sport. They double as character studies of the athletes, including a free-diver who offers a tidy explanation of his passion: I am happy when I am in the deep.

title: NASCAR Releases Image of Noose Found in Bubba Wallaces Garage
description: NASCAR on Thursday released a photo of the noose that was found last weekend in the Talladega Superspeedway garage stall assigned to Darrell Wallace Jr., the lone black driver in NASCARs premier series, following criticism that racing officials had overreacted.

title: Australian Politicians Home Raided in Chinese Influence Inquiry
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian authorities raided the home and office of a state lawmaker on Friday as part of a sweeping investigation into allegations of a Chinese government plot to manipulate the countrys politics and policy.

title: Seven Colombian Soldiers Charged in Rape of Indigenous Girl
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Seven Colombian soldiers have been charged in the rape of a 13-year-old Indigenous girl, an announcement that has alarmed many in a nation already grappling with the militarys long record of abuse, including illegal killings and accusations of sexual assaults.

title: Trump Administration Asks Supreme Court to Strike Down Affordable Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration asked the Supreme Court late Thursday to overturn the Affordable Care Act  a move that, if successful, would bring a permanent end to the health insurance program popularly known as Obamacare and wipe out coverage for as many as 23 million Americans.

title: Eurovision Song Contest Review: Over the Top and Around the Bend
description: Balancing a hat on top of a hat, David Dobkins Eurovision Song Contest: The Story of Fire Saga tries to add even more humor to an event already legendary for its excesses and battiness. The result is a movie so eye-searingly extra it makes Mamma Mia! look bashful.

title: Chinas Military Provokes Its Neighbors, but the Message Is for the United States
description: In the same week that Chinese and Indian soldiers engaged in a deadly brawl, one of Chinas submarines cruised through the waters near Japan, prompting a scramble of aircraft and ships to track its furtive movements. Chinese fighter jets and at least one bomber buzzed Taiwans territorial airspace almost daily.

title: Why Did Kim Jong-uns Sister Become the Face of North Korea?
description: Kim Yo-jong, the only sister of North Koreas supreme leader, Kim Jong-un, is now setting the tone of the countrys foreign policy. And if he is young and belligerent, she is younger and more belligerent still.

title: Late Night Cant Believe Floridas Mask Truthers
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: New in Paperback: The Nickel Boys and Confirmation Bias
description: THE SNAKES, by Sadie Jones. (Harper Perennial, 464 pp., $16.99.) Though actual snakes do slither around the hotel where relatives have gathered in this scary novel about the corrosive effects of money and power and parenthood, our reviewer, Sarah Lyall, noted, none is as vile as the familys human reptiles. Readers will find Joness fifth work of fiction provocative and propulsive, Lyall declared, even when they suspect the author of over-egging the pudding.

description: FRIENDS AND STRANGERSBy J. Courtney Sullivan

title: When James Baldwin and Langston Hughes Reviewed Each Other
description: At the Book Review, we occasionally delve into our rich archive and discover forgotten gems. In this case, while looking for reviews by James Baldwin, we came across one by Langston Hughes  and then the unusual circumstance that they reviewed each other. In our Feb. 26, 1956 issue Hughes considered Baldwins Notes of a Native Son and on March 29, 1959  Baldwin returned the volley with a review of Hughess Selected Poems of Langston Hughes. The writers were mutually harsh but also perceptive about and alive to each others creative genius. To read the full text of the reviews, subscribers can visit Times Machine at timesmachine.nytimes.com

title: The Post-Coronavirus Cruise? Not Ready to Sail
description: W. Bradford Gary spent 10 days trapped inside a cruise ship cabin off the coast of Brazil in March while health authorities in several countries scrambled to figure out what to do with a vessel full of older people who had potentially been exposed to the coronavirus.

title: Im a Health Care Worker. You Need to Know How Close We Are to Breaking.
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  As I write this, I have just finished my ninth consecutive overnight shift as an emergency medicine physician here. At the end of each shift I go to an Airbnb, where I have been living alone for two and a half months, away from my wife and 10-year-old daughter so that I am less likely to pass the coronavirus on to them.

title: Why You Should Always Read Between the Emails
description: I had just powered up my laptop to make the final edits to an article about the British governments chaotic contact-tracing system, expecting a response from officials to the questions we had asked them the day before. I had assumed they would try to dodge the tough ones.

title: Why Did It Take a Pandemic to Show How Much Unpaid Work Women Do?
description: Womens shift into paid employment in the 20th century was one of the great economic transformations in recent history. Families began buying goods such as convenience foods, vacuum cleaners and microwaves to substitute for womens unpaid labor at home. That shift in what households buy was a primary reason for the post-World War II boom in economic growth in the United States and other rich countries.

title: Costco Discontinues Half-Sheet Cake, Apparently Because of Covid-19
description: It had been a long quarantine for Megan Engles and her family, and they desperately needed a reason to celebrate. So when their dog Linuss birthday arrived, Ms. Engles, who lives in Kansas City, Mo., did what she would do for any other special occasion: She headed to her local Costco to pick up a sheet cake. But there were none to be found.

title: Pandemic Parenting Was Already Relentless. Then Came Summer.
description: American parents spend more time and money on their children than ever  and that was before the pandemic. Now, with remote school ending for the summer and a far-from-normal fall expected, parenting is becoming only more demanding.

description: Corporate chief executives have been tripping over themselves to demonstrate their support for racial justice. Theyve taken a knee, tweeted that black lives matter, donated money to advocacy groups and affirmed their commitment to inclusion.

description: Dorian Mintzer loves her work. A 74-year-old psychologist, coach and author, she has no plan to retire, and has continued to work during the pandemic, doing teletherapy from her home in the Boston area.

description: The first tenant for one of Frank Woodworths underground bunkers wasnt a human, it was a seed. A couple of hippies called me up and asked me to build them a vault for their heirloom seeds, he said.

Biden Jr.

title: Baseball Avoided a Lost Season. But Bigger Threats May Lie Ahead.
description: The tremors are over. When major league players stick their cleats into the dirt for training camp next week, the ground below them will be still. The invisible threat to their season  the coronavirus  is still out there, of course. But the game is coming back in an unprecedented form. It will be a 60-game dash to October, not the usual cross-country, 162-game slog.

description: In late April, as new coronavirus cases in Florida were steadily decreasing, Gov. Ron DeSantis began crowing about how his state had tamed the pandemic.

description: The motion-sensing lights sense nothing. The swivel chairs do not swivel. Only one sign of life remains in the abandoned corporate floor plan: potted plants.

title: The Great Wonders Beyond the Great Reef
description: What lies off Australias Great Barrier Reef, in the Coral Sea? The region was mostly unexplored and uncharted until a recent expedition searched its dark waters, uncovering an abundance of life, weird geologic features and spectacular deep corals. The deepest forays reached down more than a mile.

title: A DNA Mix-Up Involving a Washing Machine Kept a Man in Jail for 3 Years
description: As washing machines go, the one that contributed to Roy Verrets capital murder charge was pretty average. White, Whirlpool, reliable. When detectives investigating a murder in Jeanerette, La., swabbed a dark spot on the lid in January 2017, he thought they were wasting their time.

title: A Step Toward 51
description: Today, for the first time, the House of Representatives is expected to approve statehood for Washington, D.C. The bill is likely to pass on party lines, with Democrats voting in favor and Republicans against it. Afterward, it is almost certain to die in the Republican-controlled Senate.

title: Teenager Who Threw Boy From Tate Modern Is Sentenced to at Least 15 Years
description: LONDON  A teenager who admitted he attempted to kill a 6-year-old boy by pushing him from a 10th-floor viewing platform in a shocking attack at the Tate Modern museum in London last year was sentenced to life in prison, but must serve at least 15 years,  by a British court on Friday.

title: How Progressive Candidates of Color Are Building Winning Coalitions
description: Just last month, it looked as if Amy McGrath would coast to the Democratic Senate nomination in Kentucky. A moderate former fighter pilot with strong backing from the party establishment, she had raised over $40 million, far more than all her competitors combined. From her TV ads, you would have thought she was already running against Senator Mitch McConnell in the general election.

title: Virus Dramatically Narrows Teenagers Summer Job Prospects
description: Teenagers face a tough summer job market because of the pandemic and the related economic slowdown. Whether theyre lifeguard shifts at a (now-dry) pool or counselor spots at a (shuttered) summer camp, jobs often held by young people are scarce.
