title: Dont Hate Me, but I Hate My Job
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: The Pandemic Work Diary of a Napa C.E.O.
description: Carlton McCoy, the chief executive of the storied Heitz Cellar in Napa Valley, Calif., is used to being the only black man in the room. Out of nearly 300 master sommeliers in the United States, Mr. McCoy, 36, is one of just three African-Americans.

title: Philanthropy Rises in Pandemic as Donors Heed the Call for Help
description: When the coronavirus prompted states to order residents to stay at home in March, unemployment surged around the country as huge parts of the economy slowed or stopped. Soon after, there were calls for philanthropists, charitably inclined people and even occasional donors to accelerate any giving they were planning to do.

title: A Little Chutzpah Goes a Long Way
description: Emily Abigail Waife summoned up a bit of chutzpah in 2013, after talking it over with friends. She wanted to tell Eli Michael Kaufman she had feelings for him.

title: An Accidental First Date
description: A few days before they were supposed to have their first date, in February 2018, a sharp-eyed friend of Andrea Rainess saw a man walking by the San Francisco bar that the women were waiting to enter. The man looked exactly like the picture Ms. Raines had just shared of her soon-to-be date from his profile on the League dating app.

title: High School Sweethearts a Decade Ago
description: Evelyn Rodriguez and Feliberto Gonzalo, both 27, were high school sweethearts who started dating their senior year at Union City High School in New Jersey, and in 2010 went to their prom together.

description: Katie Adams and Emily Fletcher, both neuroscience majors at Dartmouth College, were in the last term of their final year, in 2013, before they met.

title: Second Chance for First Impression
description: It took two first dates for Nuala OConnor and Peter Bass to fall in love.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend. Are you finally going to get a haircut? Maybe youre going to go roller skating, or just head out the park to watch the skaters. Or maybe you are heading to the beach or the mountains. Whatever youre up to, be sure to make time for some amazing journalism.

title: Is This Whistle the Future of Refereeing?
description: More than 140 years after it made its debut, in English soccer, the whistle is the most recognizable sound in sports.

title: Six Injured, Including Police Officer, and Suspect Is Fatally Shot in Glasgow
description: Six people, including a police officer, were injured and a male suspect was fatally shot by the police at a hotel in the Scottish city of Glasgow on Friday, according to the Scottish police.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. For her Eat column in The Times this week, Tejal Rao talked with Charlotte Rutledge, the manager of the test kitchen at King Arthur Flour, in Norwich, Vt., about the development of the companys latest hit recipe, for pan pizza (above). Its worth reading Tejals article if youre at all interested in the painstaking and difficult work of developing recipes that both work and are delicious. And its absolutely worth making the recipe this weekend because its great.

title: Morehouse Cancels Football and Cross Country Because of Coronavirus
description: ATLANTA  Morehouse College, one of the countrys most celebrated historically black colleges, said Friday that it had canceled its fall sports  football and cross country  because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Welcome to Applebees! Can I Get You Started With Some Disinfectant?
description: Go right ahead and leave a cash tip for Debi Kane, a waitress at a TGI Fridays in Corona, Calif. Shell appreciate the money, but theres a catch. Under the companys new pandemic-inspired rules, she will need to drop off those dollars in a back room, then head to a sink, take off her gloves and wash for 20 seconds. Then shell wipe her hands with paper towels and wave them in the air for a couple minutes, willing them to dry.

title: How Cities Are Trying to Avert Gridlock After Coronavirus Lockdowns
description: As coronavirus lockdowns loosen around the world, city leaders are scrambling to address a new problem: the prospect of gridlock worse than before the pandemic. From Shenzhen to Milan to Austin, officials are trying to coax people back onto buses and subways and reclaim road space for cyclists and pedestrians.

title: The Segway Was Meant to Be Much More Than a Sight Gag
description: This week, Segway announced that it will soon stop production of its famous two-wheeled Personal Transporters. Its very possible that you had already forgotten about the Segway; the company, bought by a Chinese rival in 2015, certainly had, with less than 1.5 percent of its revenue coming from the model.

title: Let Freedom Ring From Georgia
description: ATLANTA  This, an old saying goes, is the city too busy to hate, one of the few places in America where enlightened leaders, black and white, chose prosperity over prejudice and a large black middle class emerged decades ago. Birthplace of Martin Luther King Jr., cradle of the civil rights movement, Atlanta, with its gleaming towers and porch swings, was an American exception. The city managed racial conflict through compromise. It was the black mecca. Or so the story went.

title: After Death Warrant for Bear, Animal Rights Groups Demand Fair Trial
description: ROME  Officials in northeastern Italy are testing the bloodstained clothes of two men after an attack landed them in the hospital this week. Investigators hope to extract enough DNA to identify the perpetrator.

title: How Bees Avoid Bumping Into Natures Obstacle Course
description: For a human, a breeze-ruffled garden is a peaceful scene: Dandelion seeds float, leaves rustle and flowers bob their heads.

title: Amazon to Buy Zoox, in a Move Toward Self-Driving Cars
description: SEATTLE  Amazon said on Friday that it was buying the autonomous ride-hailing start-up Zoox, an ambitious move that could put the tech giant in the business of moving people and not just packages.

title: Inside the PGA Tour Bubble, Silent Fairways and Mounting Cases
description: CROMWELL, Conn.  When Sergio Garcia sank his final putt Thursday on an 18th green enveloped by a natural amphitheater customarily filled with thousands of fans, the golf balls rattle around inside the hole could be heard from 30 yards away. A minute later, as Garcia ascended a hill, the only sound was his pencil scratching a last number on a scorecard.

title: Overlooked No More: Valerie Solanas, Radical Feminist Who Shot Andy Warhol
description: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This month were adding the stories of important L.G.B.T.Q. figures.

title: Your 5-Step Guide to Navigating a Scary Stock Market
description: Investing is scary right now.

title: YouTube Personality Jenna Marbles Apologizes for Blackface Video
description: Jenna Mourey, a YouTube personality who became one of the platforms first mainstream female stars as Jenna Marbles, said Thursday that she was going to stop her channel amid a backlash over videos that she made in blackface and mocking Asian people.

title: Black Activists Wonder: Is Protesting Just Trendy for White People?
description: Cherish Patton recalled springing into action when a friend sent her a message that a New York City police officer had grabbed a petite protester by her hood and had flung her to the pavement.

title: On One Block in Brooklyn, the Citys Economic Turmoil Is on Full Display
description: The roots of one store on the block extend to Mexico, from where a 13-year-old boy left for the United States decades ago and found his footing in the food industry.

title: Starting Bonus for a Laundry Worker: How a Beach Town Wrestles With Jobless Benefits
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del.  Kelsey McGarry went back to her job at Thompson Island Brewing Company in Rehoboth Beach, Del., in April even though doing so meant that she was earning less than she would have simply by accepting unemployment insurance, which included an extra $600 per week.

title: Haim Steps Into a New Groove on Women in Music Pt. III
description: Haim makes music of forward momentum, soundtracks for strutting confidently away from trouble. Its most memorable videos feature the trios members  the sisters Alana, Danielle and Este Haim  marching in loose lock step with one another, occasionally bursting into playful choreography. Its a visual trope that lets them have some revisionist fun with girl group iconography, but its also a natural extension of their percussive sound. We like rhythm, Danielle said in a 2013 interview, after the release of their debut album, Days Are Gone. Its all these parts interlocking.

title: This One-Pan Meal Shows Just How Joyful Tofu Can Be
description: Tofus versatility is no secret, but to embrace its many uses is an exquisite thing  it can be pan-fried, grilled, blended into spreads and dressings, or tossed in a smoker for a few hours. Those who know tofu well understand it as an ingredient that is subtle and ever-so-slightly sweet, a willing canvas for flavors or a base for them to intermingle.

title: Lockdown? What Lockdown? Heat Wave Brings Britons Out in Droves
description: LONDON  They descended by the tens of thousands on Britains southern beaches and jammed into city parks. They cavorted by the hundreds in streams. They attacked police officers who tried to disperse illegal block parties. And hundreds became stuck in mud flats while trying to reach the sea at low tide.

title: Fresh and Satisfying
description: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. My quarantine diet has shifted considerably in recent weeks: I now have way more access to fresh greens, which has meant salads galore. This windfall has reminded me that a great salad is a true luxury. (I am also devouring berries, fresh and baked into desserts like Jerrelle Guys strawberry spoon cake, an instant classic that is even easier to make than this famously easy plum torte. I served my spoon cake with ice cream and basil.)

title: Psychological Thrillers That Will Mess With Your Head
description: Summer is full upon us, and what we need most are thrillers to take us out of our own heads. Along comes THIS LITTLE FAMILY (Other Press, 264 pp., paper, $15.99), a short, sharp debut by the French author Ins Bayard, which has murder in its first paragraph. Marie, a young Parisian mother, laces a lovingly prepared meal with poison and feeds it to her husband and her toddler before eating it herself. The worst part, perhaps, is that one of them survives.

description: LONDON  When 50 British scientists and government officials got on a Zoom call on May 7, emotions were running high, and not just because Britain had overtaken Italy for having the highest death toll from the coronavirus in Europe.

title: The Triumph of Merseyball: How Liverpool Won the Premier League
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Gingerly, Liverpools players clasped each others hands and turned toward the Kop, Anfields iconic, sweeping grandstand. Many of them felt awkward, unsure. They had never done this before. Some wanted to leave the field as soon as possible; all they had done was draw at home with West Bromwich Albion. The point they had earned had moved them up to ninth in the Premier League table.

title: Lester Crystal, Guiding Force Behind NewsHour, Dies at 85

Crystal, who after 20 years at NBC News, including two as its president, moved to The MacNeil/Lehrer Report on PBS and immediately set about transforming it from a half-hour program into The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour, a broadcast widely acclaimed for its breadth and depth, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: The Old World Turns to a New World Spirit: Rye
description: FIFE, Scotland  Single-malt whiskies are the pride of Scotland, where strict regulations require that they be made only from malted barley. But at the five-year-old InchDairnie Distillery in Fife, some 30 miles north of Edinburgh, many of the stacked oak casks in the warehouse are filled with a spirit primarily made from a different grain: rye.

title: Going Up? Not So Fast: Strict New Rules to Govern Elevator Culture
description: Kiss the elevator pitch goodbye  at least if it takes place in an elevator.

title: Watch This Protest Turn From Peaceful to Violent in 60 Seconds
description: As a former police officer, Ive handled large protests. What I saw in Seattle disturbed me.

title: India to Screen Capitals 29 Million Residents After Coronavirus Spike
description: As the nationwide caseload surged toward 500,000 and pushed many hospitals to their breaking point, officials said they planned to survey all of New Delhis residents for the virus in the next 10 days.

title: Russia Secretly Offered Afghan Militants Bounties to Kill U.S. Troops, Intelligence Says
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence officials have concluded that a Russian military intelligence unit secretly offered bounties to Taliban-linked militants for killing coalition forces in Afghanistan  including targeting American troops  amid the peace talks to end the long-running war there, according to officials briefed on the matter.

title: Iraq Raids Iranian-Backed Militia Accused of Attacking U.S. Forces
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi forces raided an Iranian-backed militia suspected of carrying out a spate of rocket attacks against American forces, making good on the new prime ministers promise to crack down on armed groups that have strained relations with the United States.

title: For Small Businesses, Its All About the Pivot
description: To paraphrase a line from the real estate industry, small businesses, hit by the economic impact of the coronavirus, have had to pivot, pivot, pivot to survive.

title: Make Cornmeal Muffins for Your Next Breakfast Treat
description: Muffins are just an excuse to eat cake for breakfast. Or at least, that applies to the kind of muffins I like to make, which should be tender, finely textured and almost sweet enough for dessert, but not quite.

title: In Historic Vote, House Approves Statehood for the District of Columbia
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives voted nearly along party lines on Friday to grant statehood to Washington, D.C., the first time a chamber of Congress has approved establishing the nations capital as a state.

title: A Fashion Designers Reimagining of a Quinoa Bowl
description: In One Good Meal, we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis  and not just when theyre trying to impress.

title: Can Covid Damage the Brain?
description: For three months, Chelsea Alionar has struggled with fevers, headaches, dizziness and a brain fog so intense it feels like early dementia. She came down with the worst headache of her life on March 9, then lost her sense of taste and smell. She eventually tested positive for the coronavirus. But her symptoms have been stranger, and lasted longer, than most.

title: House Fails to Override Trumps Veto Limiting Student Loan Debt Relief
description: WASHINGTON  The House tried and failed on Friday to invalidate stringent rules imposed by the Trump administration on student loan forgiveness, falling short of overriding a veto by President Trump.

title: CVS, Dunkin, Lego: The Brands Pulling Ads From Facebook Over Hate Speech
description: Facebook is seeing a growing boycott by advertisers unhappy with its handling of misinformation and hate speech, including its laissez-faire attitude toward recent posts from President Trump.

title: E.U. Plans to Bar Most U.S. Travelers When Bloc Reopens
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union is ready to bar most travelers from the United States, Russia, and dozens of other countries considered too risky because they have not controlled the coronavirus outbreak, E.U. officials said Friday.

title: TikTok Grandma Who Helped Tank Trump Rally Now Works for Biden
description: Last weekend, Mary Jo Laupp was enjoying a quiet night at a birthday party for her granddaughter  until she picked up her phone and her world flipped upside down.

title: Police Not Treating Glasgow Episode as Terrorism, Scotlands First Minister Says
description: Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, thanked police officers on Friday for their response to an incident in Glasgow and said that investigations were ongoing.

title: Supreme Court Turns Down Request to Allow All Texans to Vote by Mail
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not require Texas to let all eligible voters vote by mail.

title: 17 Rikers Guards Will Be Disciplined in Death of Transgender Woman
description: Seventeen New York City correction officers, including a captain, will be disciplined for their roles in the death just over a year ago of a 27-year-old transgender woman at the Rikers Island jail complex, officials said on Friday.

title: Thomas Blanton, Who Bombed a Birmingham Church, Dies at 82
description: Thomas E. Blanton Jr., the last survivor of three Ku Klux Klansmen who were convicted in the church bombing that killed four black girls in 1963 in Birmingham, Ala.  a case that stands as one of the ugliest and most galvanizing crimes of the civil rights era  died in prison on Friday in Bessemer, Ala. He was 82.

title: Worker Fatally Shoots 2 and Injures One at Illinois Warehouse, Officials Say
description: Two workers at a coffee dispenser warehouse in Springfield, Ill., were fatally shot and another critically wounded after a co-worker opened fire on Friday morning, the authorities said.

title: Living Through Unemployment
description: On Wednesdays show, we spoke with three women  Nicolle Nordman, Anala Rodrguez and Nakitta Long  about their experiences living with unemployment as a result of the pandemic. These interviews were conducted a few weeks ago; below, our reporters share updates on how our guests have been doing in the time since.

title: Facebook Adds Labels for Some Posts as Advertisers Pull Back
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook rolled out measures on Friday to add more context to problematic political posts on its site, as the social network grappled with a growing outcry from some of its largest advertisers over the issue of hateful speech.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Trumps Diversion of Military Funds for Border Wall
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled on Friday that the Trump administration did not have the authority to transfer $2.5 billion from the Pentagon to President Trumps border wall without congressional approval, most likely sending the matter to the Supreme Court.

title: Who Gets Lifesaving Care? Tennessee Changes Rules After Federal Complaint
description: Health officials on Friday announced sweeping changes to guidelines in Tennessee on who would get lifesaving treatments, and who would not, if resources fell dramatically short during a medical crisis like the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Surge, Afghanistan, Pride Month: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Many Students Will Be in Classrooms Only Part of the Week This Fall
description: As school districts across the country began to reveal reopening plans this week, parents and students were forced to grapple with a difficult reality: It is unlikely that many schools will return to a normal schedule this fall, requiring the grind of online learning, makeshift child care and stunted workdays to continue.

title: How the Coronavirus Short-Circuits the Immune System
description: At the beginning of the pandemic, the coronavirus looked to be another respiratory illness. But the virus has turned out to affect not just the lungs, but the kidneys, the heart and the circulatory system  even, somehow, our senses of smell and taste.

title: Resist Fear-Based Parenting
description: In a 1960 study, babies were coaxed by their mothers to crawl atop plexiglass over a sharp drop in the floor. The surface was smooth, and safe, but appeared perilous to the hapless infants. It was the visual cliff experiment, a classic of developmental psychology, meant to demonstrate something about infant depth perception.

title: N.W.S.L. Players Kneel for Anthem as League Returns to Field
description: It almost didnt feel like a choice to Kaiya McCullough. She was 19, a U.C.L.A. sophomore with hopes of becoming a professional womens soccer player, when she first decided to take a knee during the national anthem.

title: Despite Virus Spike, N.B.A. Is Very Comfortable With Florida Plan
description: Despite what Adam Silver, the N.B.A. commissioner, described as an increased level of concern over a significant rise of coronavirus cases in Florida, the league moved forward on several fronts Friday by formalizing its plans to restart the 2019-20 season at Walt Disney World near Orlando.

title: After Functioning for 28 Days, U.S. Election Regulator Will Be Powerless Again
description: As the 2020 campaign enters its final months, the independent regulator of Americas elections will once again be without enough commissioners to do its job starting in July.

title: New Numbers Showing Coronavirus Spread Intrude on a White House in Denial
description: [Follow our Election Day live tracker.]

title: Mexico City Police Chief Is Wounded in Brazen Ambush
description: Gunmen wounded Mexico Citys chief of police on Friday, and killed two of his bodyguards and a bystander, in a brazen ambush on his vehicle as it traveled through a wealthy neighborhood that is home to ambassadors and business leaders.

title: As Cases Surge, Pence Misleads on Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Vice President Mike Pence defended the Trump administrations response to the coronavirus pandemic at a news briefing on Friday and sounded notes of optimism, while acknowledging that cases were rising precipitously in the South.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci, speaking today at the White House coronavirus task force briefing for the first time in nearly two months, warned that outbreaks in the South and West are threatening to engulf the country.

title: Justice Dept. to Take Aim at Antigovernment Extremists
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General William P. Barr said on Friday that he had created a task force to investigate antigovernment extremists on the far right and left who have used the nationwide policing protests as cover to attack law enforcement officers and destroy property, according to a Justice Department memo.

title: 3 Die in New Mexico After Drinking Hand Sanitizer, Officials Say
description: Three people have died, three are in critical condition, and one is permanently blind after ingesting hand sanitizer that contained methanol, the New Mexico Department of Health announced Friday.

title: Leaders Re-examine U.S. Reopenings as Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record
description: MIAMI  As coronavirus cases surge across much of the United States, leaders are urgently rethinking their strategies to curb the spread, which the nations top infectious disease expert said on Friday were not working.

title: After the Statues Fall
description: Regarding statues, monuments, and other public tributes to those once deemed great  which to do away with and which to keep  four familiar words can guide our choices: a more perfect union.

title: White Actors Leaving Nonwhite Roles at The Simpsons and Family Guy
description: For the Fox comedies The Simpsons and Family Guy, two of the most prominent and longest running animated series on television, announcements Friday outlined major shifts in the use of white actors to play characters of color on those shows.

title: 7 Killed in Crash in El Paso After Border Patrol Tried to Stop Car
description: Seven people were killed and three were seriously injured in a crash in El Paso, Texas, early Thursday morning after border patrol agents tried to stop the car they were in, the police said.

title: A Bit of Relief: The Long Distance Chorus
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Judge Orders Roger Stone to Report to Prison Next Month
description: [Read more on Roger Stones sentence being commuted by President Trump.]

title: U.S. Must Release Children From Family Detention Centers, Judge Rules
description: Citing the severity of the coronavirus pandemic, a federal judge in Los Angeles on Friday ordered the release of migrant children held in the countrys three family detention centers.

title: Styling Substance
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Ryan McCarty often plays around with interesting geometry and always constructs very cerebral yet fun puzzles with a lot of musical notes  plenty of cocktail party fodder, but also good stuff for your playlist. Todays grid isnt laid out that strangely, but it has nine debuts, many of them tough, and some excellent cluing that also adds to the challenge. I had a bit of trouble breaking in, but I would say that this is a puzzle that runs once youve built the momentum.

title: Milton Glaser, Master Designer of I  NY Logo, Is Dead at 91
description: Milton Glaser, a graphic designer who changed the vocabulary of American visual culture in the 1960s and 70s with his brightly colored, extroverted posters, magazines, book covers and record sleeves, notably his 1967 poster of Bob Dylan with psychedelic hair and his I  NY logo, died on Friday, his 91st birthday, in Manhattan.

title: Trump Issues Executive Order Targeting Vandalism Against Monuments
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump issued an executive order on Friday that instructed federal law enforcement authorities to prosecute people who damage federal monuments or statues and that threatened to withhold funding from local governments that fail to protect their own statues from vandals.

title: Honor Americas Birthday (Safely) in 2020
description: This year, Fourth of July revelers will have to swap many traditions  peppy parades, large family reunions and patriotic concerts  with low-key celebrations. But there are plenty of safe ways to commemorate Americas birthday. Here are some suggestions.

title: Quotation of the Day: A Conviction Vacated, but Only After a 25-Year Prison Term
description: Everyone in the criminal justice system failed you in some way or another.

title: Corrections: June 27, 2020
description: A map with an article on May 31 about a clash in the Himalayas between India and China included outdated boundaries for Jammu and Kashmir. The India-controlled area just west of the Line of Actual Control is the territory of Ladakh, not Jammu and Kashmir.

title: In Seizing Control, China Sidelines Its Allies in Hong Kong
description: BEIJING  Chinas Communist Party has long pursued its agenda in Hong Kong by working through loyalists among the citys top officials, lawmakers and tycoons. That behind-the-scenes approach was a key feature in preserving considerable autonomy for the territory.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Dark and a Star-Studded Global Citizen Concert
description: DARK Stream on Netflix. This incredibly complex and inventive German sci-fi series starts out as so many other mystery thrillers do, with the disappearance of young boy. But as the series progresses, the mystery surrounding the boy, who vanished in a forest, grows deeper and more bizarre  involving time travel, an apocalyptic event, a secretive society and the existence of multiple universes. The series, which returns for a third and final season, focuses on the secrets and intertwined histories of four local families, spanning multiple generations. As much as the show is a heady, brain-bending exploration into the physics and ethics of time travel, it also poses some thought-provoking questions concerning the nature of free will.

title: How College Sports Spurred Mississippi to Seriously Reconsider Its Flag
description: It was just before 9 a.m. last Friday when Philip Gunn, the speaker of the Mississippi House of Representatives, received a phone call from a lobbyist for Mississippi State University.

title: Obamacare Faces Unprecedented Test as Economy Sinks
description: The Affordable Care Act, the landmark health law that has been a subject of caustic debate for more than a decade, is being tested as never before, as millions of Americans lose their jobs and medical coverage in the midst of the nations gravest health crisis in a century.

title: About 38% of U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Are Linked to Nursing Homes
description: The virus has devastated residents and staff members in more than 23,000 long-term care facilities across the country.

title: Train Your Muscles Without a Gym
description: Now that stay-at-home restrictions are easing, those of us interested in strong, healthy muscles but wearied by burpees in the living room may want to consider heading to the nearest reopened park or playground for weight training. Experts note that you can perform most standard exercises there if youre willing to use your imagination  you can even recruit your children to help as giggling, resistance-adding workout partners. What follows are a few moves for a full-body, sun-drenched routine. (Wear a face mask, observe social distancing and use gloves or hand sanitizer to protect yourself and others, of course.)

title: Biden Still Wants to Close Guantnamo Prison
description: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

title: Five Years and 100-Plus Stories: What Its Like Covering Hamilton
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Missing the Olympics? Organize Your Own Games, at Home
description: Watching athletes compete in the Summer Olympic Games is a long-awaited highlight for millions around the world. Its a ritual that comes every four years  a chance to escape the heat, crank up the air conditioning and watch televised events like basketball games, track-and-field relays and table tennis matches. But with the coronavirus outbreak forcing the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo to be postponed, viewers will have to wait another year.

title: Give Yourself the Perfect Summer Pedicure
description: After months of shoving your feet into thick, slouchy socks  and boots, if you ventured out  its past time for your toes to see a little sunlight. But theyre likely to need at least a little T.L.C., lest you risk offending the members of your quarantine pod. Follow this step-by-step (no pun intended) guide to give yourself a safe summer pedicure. And, yes, these instructions can also be followed by the manliest of readers.

title: EBays Critics Faced an Extreme Case of an Old Silicon Valley Habit
description: Last summer, members of eBays private security team sent live roaches and a bloody pig mask to the home of a suburban Boston couple who published a niche e-commerce newsletter.

title: How Trump and the Black Lives Matter Movement Changed White Voters Minds
description: A majority of American voters support the demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice that have roiled the country over the past month, embracing ideas about bias within the criminal justice system and the persistence of systemic racism that are central tenets of the Black Lives Matter movement, according to a new national poll of registered voters by The New York Times and Siena College.

title: The Black Officer Who Detained George Floyd Had Pledged to Fix the Police
description: MINNEAPOLIS  There were two black men at the scene of the police killing in Minneapolis last month that roiled the nation. One, George Floyd, was sprawled on the asphalt, with a white officers knee on his neck. The other black man, Alex Kueng, was a rookie police officer who held his back as Mr. Floyd struggled to breathe.

title: A Reckoning With Race to Ensure Diversity for Americas Face Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  Tianna Spears dreamed for years of becoming an American diplomat. She quit in January after two, and says she will never return to the State Department, given what she has described as its failure to protect her from racial discrimination  from the United States government  while on the job.

title: Assaulted at 15, a Writer Looks Back and Comes Forward
description: There are so many upsetting things about the assault Lacy Crawford suffered in 1990, when she was 15 and a junior at St. Pauls School in New Hampshire, but one of the most upsetting is how commonplace she believes it was.

title: A True Disappointment: When Your First Pride March Is Canceled
description: Colin Beresford was looking forward to the summer of 2020, and for the first time celebrating Pride among the crowds of people in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Why Out-of-Work New Yorkers Are Starting Cooking Businesses
description: In 2013, after years of working as an art director, Miriam Weiskind gave into her love of pizza, first giving pizza tours and then making them at Paulie Gees in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: Black Trans Women Seek More Space in the Movement They Helped Start
description: Transgender women of color were leaders in L.G.B.T.Q. activism before, during and after the uprising at the Stonewall Inn 51 years ago on Sunday, but they were never put at the center of the movement they helped start: one whose very shorthand, the gay rights movement, erases them.

title: On Coronavirus, Americans Still Trust the Experts
description: For months, President Trump has been contradicting his public health advisers over the response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: PizzaGate Conspiracy Theory Thrives Anew in the TikTok Era
description: WASHINGTON  Four minutes into a video that was posted on Instagram last month, Justin Bieber leaned into the camera and adjusted the front of his black knit beanie. For some of his 130 million followers, it was a signal.

title: Say I Love You. Im Waiting.
description: The words I love you, spoken for the first time, are milestones that let you know where a romantic relationship stands.

title: Her Olympic Dream on Hold, Teen Gymnast Faces Other Trials
description: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lees first installment here.

title: How the World Missed Covid-19s Silent Spread
description: MUNICH  Dr. Camilla Rothe was about to leave for dinner when the government laboratory called with the surprising test result. Positive. It was Jan. 27. She had just discovered Germanys first case of the new coronavirus.

title: We Live From the Tourists: Orlando Workers Face Viruss Fallout
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Four thousand phone calls.

title: Welcome to Your School Reunion! No Name Tags Required
description: Full disclosure: I have never attended a school reunion. Nor am I likely, even during lockdown, to make that group journey down memory lane.

title: Make It the Summer of the Mocktail
description: Making an alcohol-free cocktail can be as simple as opening a can of Bloody Mary mix, but with a little more ambition, the home bartender can create tasty, refreshing and intriguing drinks.

title: U.S. States Backtrack on Reopening as Coronavirus Cases Climb
description: This briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

title: Micheal Martin Becomes Irelands Prime Minister as Rival Parties Ally
description: DUBLIN  Irelands Parliament appointed Micheal Martin, a center-right politician, as prime minister on Saturday as the country deals with the coronavirus and fallout from a housing crisis.

title: Afghan Deaths Pile Up in Uncertainty Over U.S. Deal With Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two employees of Afghanistans human rights commission were killed in Kabul on Saturday as a bomb attached to their vehicle exploded, the latest in a rising number of targeted killings in the Afghan capital.

title: French Soccers Renegade President Would Like a Word. With Everyone.
description: Jean-Michel Aulas has been watching a lot of soccer in recent weeks. His emotions have been mixed.

title: How Americans Feel About the Country Right Now: Anxious. Hopeful.
description: Amanda Vibelius, a stay-at-home mother in rural Arizona, is angry and overwhelmed.

title: Preparing to Launch: Three Adolescents Count Down to Adulthood
description: Its January 1986. What do you do if youre a 12-year-old girl who feels invisible and longs to be a space shuttle commander? In Erin Entrada Kellys WE DREAM OF SPACE (Greenwillow, 400 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), Bernadatte Nelson Thomas (known as Bird) daydreams shes reaching out to Judith Resnik, an astronaut prepping for the launch of the Challenger. An imaginary Resnik talks back, telling Bird, Youre not disappearing, and describes being in space as floating in a world that belongs only to you, but also belongs to everyone else.

title: Brave Teenage Refugees Seek a Home of the Free
description: WE ARE NOT FROM HERE (Philomel, 368 pp., $17.99; ages 14 and up), by Jenny Torres Sanchez, is a novel precisely for this moment.

title: The Tangiest Key Lime Pie Bars
description: The weeks most popular dishes include Samantha Seneviratnes Key lime pie bars with vanilla wafer crust (above), Tejal Raos cheesy pan pizza and Kay Chuns sausage and peppers pasta with broccoli. Find more recipes in the collection below.

title: Hickenlooper Stumbles in Colorado Race, Complicating Democrats Senate Push
description: KREMMLING, Colo.  For months, Democrats have figured that Colorados U.S. Senate race, a linchpin of their strategy to take back the majority in November, was essentially in the bag, with the Republican incumbent Cory Gardner trailing by double digits behind their candidate John Hickenlooper, the well-liked and well-known former two-term governor and Denver mayor.

title: As the Coronavirus Spreads, Drug Pricing Legislation Remains Stalled
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump visited Senate Republicans last month for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic began ripping across the country, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the powerful chairman of the Finance Committee, confronted him about whether he still wanted to fulfill his years-old promise of lowering the cost of prescription drugs.

title: After Asking Americans to Sacrifice in Shutdown, Leaders Failed to Control Virus
description: WASHINGTON  More than four months into fighting the coronavirus in the United States, the shared sacrifice of millions of Americans suspending their lives  with jobs lost, businesses shuttered, daily routines upended  has not been enough to beat back a virus whose staying power around the world is only still being grasped.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD  Todays cryptic was slow going for me, probably because there are hardly any anagrams, and I lean on them for letters. I found the southeast corner extremely tough! However, the efforts very worthwhile and there are some really interesting and unusual entries, once youve sorted your way through the multiple steps in most of the clues.

title: I Was in Love With a Tree That Swallowed the Sky
description: I bought my house in Oregon without ever having set foot in it, without ever having even been to the state. I bought it knowing I might never make it here, that Id have to risk my life to try. In my rowhouse in the clatter of Washington, D.C., my only view was the back of another house, about as far as Id ever been able to see during years spent largely housebound with an illness that was finally beginning to let me go.

title: We Would Die of the Virus or Not. The System Would Roll On.
description: GRAFTON, Ohio  A few of us were talking at Roc and Daves bunk about writing a petition about keeping inmates safe during the pandemic. Suggestions of what to include were trickling in throughout the long, dragging day  through in-depth conversations or notes passed under the cell door.

title: From 47 Primaries, 4 Warning Signs About the 2020 Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Evelina Reese has been a poll worker for 40 years. And for the last six decades, she says, she has never missed a chance to vote.

title: Removing the Statues (T.R. and Others)
Gotten Used to Quarantine? Us Too
description: Across the country, cities and states are in various stages of reopening, even as cases of Covid-19 are rising, particularly in the South. Some people are lounging at the beach, without masks, or going out to eat and drink in restaurants and bars, where social distancing may be difficult.

title: Elly Stone, 93, Distinctive Singer in Jacques Brel Revue, Dies
description: Elly Stone, who was enjoying a moderately successful career as a singer and actress when she jumped to a new level of fame in 1968 as part of the wildly popular musical revue Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, died on June 11 in Cuenca, Ecuador. She was 93.

title: Princeton Will Remove Woodrow Wilsons Name From School
description: Princeton University will remove Woodrow Wilsons name from its public policy school and one of its residential colleges, the universitys president said on Saturday  a move that comes four years after it decided to keep the name over the objections of student protests.

title: The First Pick in the N.H.L. Draft Goes to  TBD
description: The National Hockey League on Friday held the first part of its draft lottery, an annual ritual of pro sports leagues meant to lay out an order of business for the rest of the draft process. The nights primary revelation, however, was that this years draft order is still as incomplete as the season itself.

title: Polands Virus-Delayed Presidential Election Suddenly Looks Tight
description: WARSAW  Polands governing party swept to power five years ago by appealing to a sense of aggrieved nationalism, and moved quickly to transform the state in ways that critics contend has torn at the fragile fabric of its democracy.

title: Uber Rides Cost More? OK
description: The underpinning of countless Silicon Valley success stories is a method of commerce that treats millions of workers as disposable and deprives them of protections regular employees enjoy, like employer-paid health care. Keeping Uber drivers and DoorDash food couriers classified as contractors saves the companies billions in costs and has helped fuel billions more in investor value.

title: Actual Coronavirus Infections Vastly Undercounted, C.D.C. Data Shows
description: The number of coronavirus infections in many parts of the United States is more than 10 times higher than the reported rate, according to data released on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Mississippi Lawmakers Push Ahead With Proposal to Take Down State Flag
description: Update: In a ceremony on Tuesday evening, Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi signed into law the legislation replacing the state flag.

title: Dr. William Dement, Leader in Sleep Disorder Research, Dies at 91
description: Dr. William Dement, whose introduction to the mysteries of slumber as a postgraduate student in the 1950s led him to become an eminent researcher of sleep disorders and to preach the benefits of a good nights sleep, died on June 17 in Stanford, Calif. He was 91.

title: Trump, Not So Statuesque
description: WASHINGTON  For a long time, Republicans have brandished the same old narrative to try to scare their way into the White House.

title: Now Is a Time to Learn From Hispanic Americans
description: CORNELIUS, Ore.  Scholars call it the Hispanic Paradox: Despite poverty and discrimination, Hispanic Americans live significantly longer than white or black Americans.

title: Waking Up in 2030
description: There is something peculiar about time during the pandemic. On the one hand theres a feeling that the normal calendar has simply stopped, school schedules and sports seasons evaporating, one homebound day passing much like another. Its a feeling of hiatus, intermission, like the days between Christmas and the new year, or some extra season invented by a Renaissance pope to fix a lagging calendar.

title: Bidens Best Veep Pick Is Obvious
description: Whatever his wobbles, Joe Biden has, from the start of his presidential campaign, got one thing exactly right: The 2020 election is a battle for the soul of America. Thats not just a pretty slogan. Its the stomach-knotting truth  and its the frame he should use for choosing his running mate.

title: San Antonio Strong
description: SAN ANTONIO  Austin Wondzells midnight blue S.U.V. was one of the nearly 2,000 vehicles winding through a stadium parking lot on a Friday morning in mid-May.

title: Power-Ups
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays puzzle is a bicoastal double debut from Jon Schneider, a research scientist at Google in New York City, and Anderson Wang, a software engineer in California. The two met at M.I.T. and bonded over solving and constructing together. (Shout out to any zoom or skype group solvers out there! What a world.)

title: Activists Push for Removal of Statue of Freed Slave Kneeling Before Lincoln
description: As communities across the country reconsider statues and monuments of historical figures, protesters in Washington, D.C., are increasing calls to remove the Emancipation Memorial, a statue of a freed slave crouching before President Abraham Lincoln, after attempts in the past week to tear it down have intensified the debate over its value.

title: A Cure for Heart Disease? A Single Shot Succeeds in Monkeys
description: What if a single injection could lower blood levels of cholesterol and triglycerides  for a lifetime?

title: Starbucks Barista Gets $87,000 in Donations After Customers Mask Complaint
description: A Starbucks barista in San Diego has more than $87,000 to fuel his dream of teaching dance after an online fund-raiser was created in response to a Facebook post by a customer who was not wearing a mask complaining about him and the companys policies.

title: Houston Moves to Severe Covid Warning. Will Enough People Listen?
description: HOUSTON  Alex Belt, a single mother of three girls and the owner of Silly Silly Girls gift boutique, has a succinct way of describing her life in Houston as officials warn of an alarming spike in coronavirus cases: Business as usual without the business.

title: Biden Campaign Says Just Over a Third of 2020 Staff Members Are People of Color
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. released statistics on the diversity of his presidential campaign staff on Saturday evening, announcing that 35 percent of his full-time staff members and 36 percent of his full-time senior staff members are people of color.

title: 2 Dead in Shooting at Walmart Distribution Center in California, Including Gunman
description: A shooting on Saturday by a former worker at a Walmart distribution center in Red Bluff, Calif., left an employee dead and several others injured, the authorities said.

title: Mississippi Votes to Remove Confederate Emblem From State Flag
description: Mississippi state legislators voted, 85 to 34, to remove the states flag from its Capitol and begin creating a new flag that no longer contains the Confederate battle emblem.

title: Quotation of the Day: For Black NASCAR Fans, It Can Be Lonely at the Track
description: We have a flag. Its the United States flag. Im cool with that one.

title: Biden Criticizes Trump Over Intelligence on Russian Bounties on U.S. Troops
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. assailed President Trump on Saturday for failing to punish Russia for offering bounties to the Taliban to kill American troops in Afghanistan, while the White House denied that Mr. Trump had been briefed on the months-old classified intelligence assessment about Russias activities.

title: What Chinas New National Security Law Means for Hong Kong
description: Chinese lawmakers have approved a national security law, drastically curbing political protest and dissent in Hong Kong and adding to Beijings tensions with Western powers.

title: 1 Dead After Man Shoots Into Crowd at Breonna Taylor Protest Site
description: A fatal shooting in Louisville on Saturday night added a grim note to weeks of protests against police violence and particularly against the killing there in March of Breonna Taylor, an African-American emergency room technician shot to death by police in her home.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: The BET Awards and Ill Be Gone in the Dark
description: 2020 BET AWARDS 8 p.m. on BET and CBS. While some awards have postponed their ceremonies, this annual show, which celebrates the work of black artists, athletes and entertainers, is still a go. Now in its 20th year, the BET Awards will feature performances by Alicia Keys, Future, DaBaby and more. Rather than sing from their couches, the artists prerecorded their own segments from all sorts of settings, using open venues, public spaces and, of course, their creativity. Drake leads with six nominations, followed by Megan Thee Stallion and Roddy Rich, who each have five. Other artists with multiple nods include Beyonc, Nicki Minaj and Chris Brown. The comedian Amanda Seales hosts.

title: We Noticed a Man Who Was Standing in the Street Near the Curb
description: Dear Diary:

title: African Migrants in Yemen Scapegoated for Coronavirus Outbreak
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Yemeni militiamen rumbled up to the settlement of Al Ghar in the morning, firing their machine guns at the Ethiopian migrants caught in the middle of somebody elses war. They shouted at the migrants: Take your coronavirus and leave the country, or face death.

title: When the Room With a View Is Kevin Kwans, Things Might Get Wild
description: Its been seven years since Kevin Kwans Crazy Rich Asians took the world of escapist shopaholic fantasy by storm. That was so long ago that Kwans funniest Hong Kong arriviste, Eddie Chen, could use Astor, Trump and Vanderbilt as the names of his dogs. That book, which grew into a wildly popular trilogy and film franchise, made the Marie Antoinette-ing of the Singaporean superrich both freakish and fascinating. So much about the extravagance and snobbery of the books clashing Asian elites was not globally known.

title: Trump Faces Mounting Defections From a Once-Loyal Group: Older White Voters
description: Clifford Wagner, an 80-year-old Republican in Tucson, Ariz., never cared for President Trump.

title: How Michael Flynns Defense Team Found Powerful Allies
description: WASHINGTON  Sidney Powell, a firebrand lawyer whose pugnacious Fox News appearances had earned her numerous private phone conversations with President Trump, sent a letter last year to Attorney General William P. Barr about her soon-to-be new client, Michael T. Flynn.

title: We Could Be Feeling This for the Next Decade: Virus Hits College Towns
description: DAVIS, Calif.  The community around the University of California, Davis, used to have a population of 70,000 and a thriving economy. Rentals were tight. Downtown was jammed. Hotels were booked months in advance for commencement. Students swarmed to the towns bar crawl, sampling the trio of signature cocktails known on campus as the Davis Trinity.

title: The Lost Spring
description: UNION, N.J.  At high schools across America, senior night is bittersweet even in the best of times. This year, it became just another milestone, alongside senior proms and graduation ceremonies, erased from the calendar by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Surge, Mississippi, Stonewall Inn: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: TikTok Is Shaping Politics. But How?
description: As a place where millions of young Americans perform and explore their identities in public, TikTok has become a prominent venue for ideological formation, political activism and trolling. It has homegrown pundits, and despite its parent companys reluctance to be involved with politics  the service does not allow political ads it has attracted interest from campaigns. It is also a space where people can be gathered and pressed into action quickly.

title: The Week in Business: Dont Say You Werent Warned
description: Have a safe and socially distanced July Fourth. You know the rules, annoying as they are. And fresh outbreaks in many states prove the dangers of wishful thinking. Heres what else you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech.

title: The Global Death Toll Now Tops 500,000
description: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

title: Voters in Poland Appear to Force a Runoff for President
description: WARSAW  Polands president, Andrzej Duda, fell short of securing a majority of the vote Sunday in Europes first socially distanced election, exit polls showed, forcing a runoff vote in two weeks against the second-place finisher, Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski of Warsaw.

title: The Sunday Read: The Man Who Saw America
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Taiwan Celebrates Pride With a Public Parade
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  With the coronavirus pandemic making large gatherings impossible in many places, the biggest Pride events around the globe were mostly forced to scale back or move online.

title: In And She Could Be Next, Women of Color Take on Politics
description: When the directors Grace Lee and Marjan Safinia talk about their new two-part documentary series, And She Could Be Next, they compare the process of getting it greenlit to mounting a political campaign.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. A number of years ago, my friend and colleague Tejal Rao met up with a sous chef named Julia Goldberg at the vegetarian restaurant Superiority Burger in New York, where Goldberg then worked. Tejal had come to learn the secrets of one of Goldbergs most elegant creations: A vegan ranch dressing (above), tangy and creamy, Tejal wrote for The Times, turbocharged with the familiar mouth-smacking umami of bottled ranch.

title: Excavating Chinese History, One Harrowing Film at a Time
description: For more than 20 years, the filmmaker Hu Jie has been trawling the deep waters of Chinese history to create a series of harrowing documentaries about the early years of Communist Party rule.

title: Who Will Get to Swim This Summer?
description: Like other crises in the past, the coronavirus pandemic has provided an opportunity for communities to act on their most exclusionary impulses. This summer, private pools and beach clubs, as well as public facilities in wealthier areas, are reopening with new measures to ensure that the general public stays out: hiring more security, aggressively checking beach tags and restricting access to residents only.

title: How Texas Swaggered Into a Coronavirus Disaster
description: HOUSTON  For one brief, delusional moment in early April, I felt a smidgen of support for my governor, Greg Abbott. Sure, part of me thought his plan to reopen the state after just a few weeks of lockdown was cuckoo. Medical experts warned of a surge in coronavirus cases if Texas did just that.

title: Montaigne Fled the Plague, and Found Himself
description: In the summer of 1585, the mayor of Bordeaux learned, from the comfort of his nearby chateau, that the bubonic plague had burst upon his city. Those who could were fleeing, he was told, while those who could not were dying like flies. What to do? His term in office, on the one hand, was nearly over and his last official duty was to attend the transition ceremony. On the other hand, perhaps his duty was with those still inside the city walls.

title: With Flights Banned, Son Sails Solo Across Atlantic to Reach Father, 90
description: BUENOS AIRES  Days after Argentina canceled all international passenger flights to shield the country from the new coronavirus, Juan Manuel Ballestero began his journey home the only way possible: He stepped aboard his small sailboat for what turned out to be an 85-day odyssey across the Atlantic.

title: Its Time for OSHA to Do Its Job
Can We Reach a Consensus on Gay Rights and Religion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Beaten by Police Is Longtime Fighter for Indigenous Rights
description: TORONTO  He survived Canadas notoriously abusive schools for Indigenous children and went on to lead his own nation. He battled governments and oil giants over the pollution of his traditional territory, garnering him the praise and admiration of Desmond Tutu, Greta Thunberg and celebrities like Leonardo DiCaprio.

title: Why the $6 Billion N.Y.P.D. Is Now a Target of Defund the Police
description: When someone in the grip of a mental health emergency behaves erratically in New York City, it is the Police Department that is often called in. When there are serious disciplinary problems in the schools, or when homeless people are found sleeping in the subways, police officers are asked to take over.

title: Majestic Icon or Invasive Pest? A War Over Australias Wild Horses
description: ANGLERS REST, Australia  Coming over the rise, Philip Maguire gripped the mane of his white gelding and rose on his heels to survey the bush land. He had hoped to be photographed mustering wild horses, but the animals werent playing along.

title: Charles Webb, Elusive Author of The Graduate, Dies at 81
description: Charles Webb, who wrote the 1963 novel The Graduate, the basis for the hit 1967 film, and then spent decades running from its success, died on June 16 in East Sussex, England. He was 81.

title: White House Blames Rise in Virus Cases on More Testing, as Experts Dispute the Claim
description: Vice President Mike Pence and the nations top health official, Alex M. Azar II, continued to assert on Sunday that reopenings in many states were not causing the sharp rises in coronavirus cases, but rather that increased testing was uncovering more and more infections.

title: Trump Retweets Racist Video Showing Supporter Yelling White Power
description: [Follow our Election Day live tracker.]

title: How the Floyd Protests Turned Into a 24-Hour Occupy City Hall in N.Y.
description: It started on Tuesday night when about 100 protesters began occupying City Hall Park in Lower Manhattan  with some spending the night  in an effort to draw more focus to their demand for deep budget cuts to the Police Department.

title: Broadway League Pledges Change Amid National Uproar Over Racism
description: The Broadway League, a trade association that is the closest thing to a governing body presiding over Americas biggest stages, has decided to undertake a sweeping audit of diversity in the industry in response to the unrest over racial injustice that is sweeping the nation.

title: How the Virus and Protests Changed a 50-Year Celebration of Pride
description: Not six months ago, the idea of this years Pride March in New York City, on the 50th anniversary of the first parade, would have conjured images of colorful floats, elaborate costumes and hundreds of thousands of revelers packed into city streets.

title: Boeing Gets Go-Ahead for Test Flights of Its Troubled 737 Max
description: Boeing has received Federal Aviation Administration approval to start test flights of its 737 Max to demonstrate that it can fly safely with new flight control software. The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, represent a major step in the companys effort to get its best-selling plane flying again.

title: Linda Cristal, Who Starred in High Chaparral, Dies at 89
description: Linda Cristal, an Argentine-born actress who played Victoria, the regal, fiery wife of the rancher Big John Cannon on the 1960s television series The High Chaparral, died on Saturday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 89.

title: Museum of the City of New York: Reduced but Reopening
description: Near the top of New Yorks Museum Mile, north of the Cooper Hewitt, a gem from the Gilded Age, and the Guggenheim, itself a Frank-Lloyd-Wright-work-of-art, and the classical majesty of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sits the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Lungs Review: Claire Foy and Matt Smith Chase Love in the Dark
description: The woman and man who make up the entire cast of Duncan Macmillans Lungs, which is streaming in a beautifully acted (and socially distanced) live production from Londons Old Vic Theater, are people who seldom think before they talk. Feelings  big, sloppy, mixed, unedited, self-incriminating feelings  slosh out of them like the contents of overfilled, foaming beer mugs on a wobbly tray.

title: Spies and Commandos Warned Months Ago of Russian Bounties on U.S. Troops
description: WASHINGTON  United States intelligence officers and Special Operations forces in Afghanistan alerted their superiors as early as January to a suspected Russian plot to pay bounties to the Taliban to kill American troops in Afghanistan, according to officials briefed on the matter. They believed at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties, two of the officials said.

title: 4 San Jose Officers Put on Leave Amid Probe Into Racist Facebook Posts
description: Four police officers in San Jose, Calif., have been placed on administrative leave after an anonymous blog post accused retired and current officers of posting racist and anti-Muslim comments in a private Facebook group.

title: U.S. Virus Surge, Hong Kong, Pride: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: They Want to Kill Me: Many Covid Patients Have Terrifying Delirium
description: Kim Victory was paralyzed on a bed and being burned alive.

title: Chesapeake Energy, a Shale Pioneer, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: HOUSTON  Chesapeake Energy, a pioneer in extracting natural gas from shale rock across the country, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, unable to overcome a mountain of debt that became unsustainable after a decade of stubbornly low gas prices.

title: How the Trump Campaign Is Drawing Obama Out of Retirement
description: Just after Donald J. Trump was elected president, Barack Obama slumped in his chair in the Oval Office and addressed an aide standing near a conspicuously placed bowl of apples, emblem of a healthy-snacking policy soon to be swept aside, along with so much else.

title: Pride March in New York Protests Police Brutality
description: More than 1,000 people walked in the Queer Liberation March, a Pride celebration and anti-racism protest. A brief confrontation erupted with police as protesters gathered in Washington Square Park.

title: Mike East, Who Lowered U.S. Flag in Havana in 1961, Dies at 81
description: Attired in their dress blues, Mike East and two other Marine guards at the United States Embassy in Havana carried out a melancholy mission in the winter of 1961.

title: Trumps Napalm Politics? They Began With Newt
description: Approximately one billion news cycles ago  which is to say, on June 9  a businesswoman named Marjorie Taylor Greene finished first in the Republican primary in Georgias deeply conservative 14th Congressional District, northwest of Atlanta, which means that after a runoff shes all but assured a seat in the House of Representatives next year.

title: Floridas Covid Cases Up Fivefold in 2 Weeks: The Numbers Are Scary
description: MIAMI  John Delgado has slept in a tent in his backyard for 57 nights and counting.

title: Long Lunches
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  When we last saw Peter Gordon in February, he was taking us on a tour of the states. In this puzzle, he reveals an interesting find in a set of six phrases.

title: India Debates Skin-Tone Bias as Beauty Companies Alter Ads
description: NEW DELHI  Throughout the years she was growing up in southern India, Christy Jennifer, a producer with a media house in the city of Chennai, was traumatized by episodes of prejudice.

title: Mississippi Lawmakers Vote to Retire State Flag Rooted in the Confederacy
description: Update: In a ceremony on Tuesday evening, Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi signed into law the measure replacing the state flag.

title: Yes, Even George Washington
description: On the issue of American slavery, I am an absolutist: enslavers were amoral monsters.

title: Marty Baron Made The Post Great Again. Now, the News Is Changing.
description: Almost anyone who works in the Washington Post newsroom can look inside its publishing system, Methode, to see what stories are coming. And at the height of the furor over Brett Kavanaughs nomination to the Supreme Court in 2018, some who did saw a shocking article awaiting publication.

title: Mask Exemption Cards From the Freedom to Breathe Agency? Theyre Fake
description: Cards for sale that claim to exempt people from wearing masks during the coronavirus pandemic are fraudulent, federal officials said.

title: Three Words. 70 Cases. The Tragic History of I Cant Breathe.
description: The deaths of Eric Garner in New York and George Floyd in Minnesota created national outrage over the use of deadly police restraints. There were many others you didnt hear about.

title: Defenders of Roosevelt Statue Converge on Natural History Museum
description: For more than a dozen years, Marion Reid, 77, had walked past the statue of Theodore Roosevelt on his way to work in information technology at the American Museum of Natural History, an employer that he said often failed to treat African-Americans with dignity.

title: Patriots Sign Cam Newton as N.F.L. Levies Fine in Video Scandal
description: Quarterback Cam Newton, the 2015 N.F.L. most valuable player who has been dogged by injuries in recent years, has signed a one-year contract with the New England Patriots, according to multiple reports.

title: Dustin Johnson Splashed and Rallied to a Travelers Championship Win
description: CROMWELL, Conn.  The Travelers Championship, the PGA Tours third tournament after a 90-day layoff because of the coronavirus pandemic, began last week with a flurry of positive tests for the virus among players and caddies. The event warily lurched forward.

title: Feeling Like Death: Inside a Houston Hospital Bracing for a Virus Peak
description: HOUSTON  Melissa Estrada had tried to be so careful about the coronavirus. For months she kept her three children at home, and she always wore a mask at the grocery store. She and her daughter even stitched face coverings for relatives and friends.

title: Perry Mason Season 1, Episode 2: In the Trenches
description: The flashbacks occur at intervals throughout the episode. They take us to the trenches of World War I  still without its even more savage sequel by the time Perry Mason takes place  where our title character is an American military officer, leading his men in a charge over the top. In the chaos of the no mans land, the charge breaks down. Those whove survived German machine guns and flame throwers now must contend with a huge wave of enemy troops mounting a counterattack  and the lethal poison gas clearing their way.

title: Bagged Salads Recalled After Hundreds Are Sickened in the Midwest
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is warning consumers and retailers in eight Midwestern states to stay away from some bagged salad mixes as officials investigate an outbreak of an intestinal illness caused by a microscopic parasite.

title: Coronavirus, Russian Bounties, Polands Election: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Monday: And She Could Be Next and The Sommerdahl Murders
description: OCEANS TWELVE (2004) 7:15 p.m. on AMC. This summers slate of popcorn movies has been drastically reduced by the pandemic but Steven Soderberghs sequel to Oceans Eleven could provide some of what moviegoers may be missing. In her review for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this crime comedy an enjoyable, unabashedly trivial caper flick. George Clooney returns as Danny Ocean, the leader of a gang that specializes in baroque heists. This time, his team is scheming to pay off the casino owner they robbed in the first film. To come up with the money, the crew relocates to Europe, where they quickly find themselves in competition with a master thief.

title: No Corrections: June 29, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 29, 2020.

title: Quotation of the Day: Houston Surge Fills Hospitals With the Young
description: It hit me like a truck. Even if you are young and not at risk, its pretty scary.

title: Gunmen Wage Deadly Battle at Pakistan Stock Exchange
description: Armed with assault rifles and hand grenades, separatist militants tried to storm Pakistans stock exchange in the city of Karachi on Monday, killing three people and wounding several others before security officers shot and killed the attackers, officials said.

title: Italian Soccers Fractious Chorus Tries a New Tune: Cooperation
description: Pretty quickly, Paolo Dal Pino realized that the illustrious list of names on his glittering rsum, the long years spent in the boardrooms of some of Italys corporate behemoths, the experience that had gotten him the job  none of it was fitting preparation for running his countrys top soccer league.

title: Florida Court Will Hear Video Appeal in Robert Kraft Case
description: A three-judge panel in the Florida Fourth District Court of Appeal in West Palm Beach will hear an appeal of the case against the New England Patriots owner, Robert K. Kraft, this week when it considers a lower courts decision to throw out video evidence that is central to the two misdemeanor charges against him for solicitation of prostitution. The case will be argued via videoconference beginning on June 30 and livestreamed on the courts website because of coronavirus concerns.

title: Trump Is Running on the Courts Again. Should Biden Do the Same?
description: President Trump this month celebrated the confirmation of his 200th lifetime appointment to the federal bench, outpacing his predecessor by dozens through three-and-a-half years.

title: Gerardo Parra Hopes Baby Shark Magic Can Bring a Title in Japan, Too
description: Amid all the new safety protocols and unusual scenes after the delayed opening of Japans baseball league, a highly unscientific yet intriguing multicultural study is underway: Can a Venezuelan player who became the emotional soul of an American franchises first championship run deliver similar results in Japan with his beloved Korean-produced childrens song?

title: Celebrating Pride in a Time of Protests and Pandemic
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Is It Basketball  or Socialism?
description: While nobody was looking, the N.B.A. figured out how to fight inequality.

title: New Data Reveals Hidden Flood Risk Across America
description: Nearly twice as many properties may be susceptible to flood damage than previously thought, according to a new effort to map the danger.

title: Is It Basketball  or Socialism?
description: Professional sports  the pinnacle of pure competition. Thirty N.B.A. teams stocked with the worlds best basketball players, all vying for one championship trophy.

title: The Challenges of the Pandemic for Queer Youth
description: When Brittany Brockenbroughs transgender son lost his in-school counseling and the ability to have meet-ups with other L.G.B.T.Q. youth during the pandemic, his mental health suffered.

title: Employer-Based Health Care, Meet Massive Unemployment
description: In the early months of 2020, Americans were engaged in the perennial election-year debate over how best to reform the nations health care system. As usual, the electorate was torn and confused. Polling indicated that a small majority of likely voters favored a new universal system that would cover everyone. But that support evaporated when it was made clear that any such overhaul would involve abolishing the private insurance market. At the time, nearly 160 million Americans received their health benefits through an employer, and the vast majority of them liked that coverage just fine  maybe not enough to sing about it, but enough to be wary of a potential replacement.

title: The Video Call Is Starting. Time to Put on Your Zoom Shirt.
description: Its time to log in to his first Zoom meeting of his workday, so Joe Farrell puts on a short-sleeve button-down from Brooks Brothers, in black, red and white plaid.

title: Latin America Is Ready for Its Black Lives Matter Reckoning
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  On May 18, a 14-year-old boy was playing pool with his cousin and other teenagers in a backyard in So Gonalo, in the metropolitan region of Rio de Janeiro. Police officers, in pursuit of a drug dealer, fired over 70 shots into the home, killing him. He was black. His name was Joo Pedro Matos Pinto. There have been so many others.

title: We Know How to Beat the Virus. This Is How Republicans Can Do It.
description: The coronavirus is still raging, particularly in states like Texas, Arizona and Florida. We already know what it takes to beat it. We just need to do it.

title: These Are the Heartbreaking Belongings That Covid Victims Left Behind
description: Rafael Eli, 68, stopped breathing in the early hours of April 16 after having spent 18 days on a ventilator at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.

title: The Reality Behind Below Deck
description: PALMA, Majorca  A provocative theory in vogue among physicists and philosophers suggests that we humans are not experiencing, and have not ever experienced, reality.

title: Dont Cancel That Newspaper Subscription
description: NASHVILLE  In 1954, a man called the city desk of The Tennessean, Nashvilles daily morning newspaper, to say he planned to take his own life by jumping from the Shelby Avenue Bridge. If the paper wanted the story, he said, they should send a reporter.

title: Caring for Children With Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome
description: When doctors began to recognize a serious inflammatory syndrome affecting children, apparently related in some way to Covid-19 infections, it was scary news for parents and pediatricians alike. Everyone had taken some comfort in the idea that this terrible and terrifying pandemic was in large part sparing the young.

title: Black Families Were Hit Hard by the Pandemic. The Effects on Children May Be Lasting.
description: Kourtney McGowan was furloughed in March, when the preschool she worked at closed during the coronavirus shutdown. The relationship with her longtime partner quickly crumbled under the pressure. They broke up due to mental health issues that she said started to appear with both of them being stressed out and inside all day.

title: What Do You Do When Extremism Comes for the Hawaiian Shirt?
description: Its one of the most discussed street styles of the spring: tactical body armor, customized assault rifles, maybe a sidearm and helmet, paired with the languid floral patterns of a Hawaiian shirt.

title: I Never Expected to Love Full-Time Motherhood
description: In my early adulthood I fully absorbed the queer ethos that being different was a strength, not a weakness. I imagined living a life that would challenge rather than conform to social norms, and harbored no hope (or wish) to become a wife and mother.

title: Bring On the 28th Amendment
description: What if we made voting an agent of equality, not inequality? And how can we get there?

title: The Long, Unhappy History of Working From Home
description: Three months after the coronavirus pandemic shut down offices, corporate America has concluded that working from home is working out. Many employees will be tethered to Zoom and Slack for the rest of their careers, their commute accomplished in seconds.

title: Mayor de Blasio, Bring Back Summer Jobs
description: As our country grapples with both a pandemic and the devastating impacts of long-term systemic racism, political leaders are rightfully looking to enact policies that meaningfully benefit low-income and minority communities. Many solutions will take time, but there is one action that mayors across the country  including in New York City  can take right now to support the communities hurting the most: Restore summer jobs programs for young people.

title: The Pandemic May Spare Us From Another Plague: Bedbugs
description: This years plague, the newly emerged coronavirus, will likely spare many people from being attacked by an ancient scourge: bedbugs. Given the drastic pandemic-induced reductions in travel and nights spent in hotels, motels and other venues outside ones home, the chances of being bitten by or bringing home these uninvited guests have been greatly curtailed.

title: Public Spaces Werent Designed for Pandemics. N.Y.C. Is Trying to Adapt.
description: A sweeping red-glass staircase in the heart of Times Square that is a magnet for selfie-snapping tourists has been barricaded off.

title: Shopping for Fruit Bowls
description: In an otherwise unpredictable year, summer is beginning to deliver its annual bounty of fruits and vegetables. From fragrant peaches to sculptural squashes, their scents and colors fill the kitchen.

title: Jim Carrey, Unmasked
description: Jim Carrey is not doing well at all.

title: Trumps Self-Inflicted Wound: Losing Swing Voters As He Plays to His Base
description: Since the day he was sworn into office, President Trump has pursued policies and practiced politics with a single-minded focus on bedrock Republicans, showing little interest in appealing to independent voters. That has made him one of the most powerful figures ever in his party, and rewarded him with strong conservative support in his re-election campaign.

title: How Jos Andrs Faces the Challenge of Feeding Millions
description: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times  what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.

title: Swimming With the Sea Lions of Los Islotes
description: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series  The World Through a Lens  in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planets most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Benjamin Lowy shares a collection of photos from an underwater shoot off the coast of Baja.

title: Coronavirus Is Battering Africas Growing Middle Class
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  James Gichina started out 15 years ago as a driver shuttling travelers from the airport, worked his way up to safari guide, and with the help of some bank loans, bought two minivans of his own to ferry vacationers around.

title: Extraordinarily Uncertain Outlook From Powell
States Pause Plans to Reopen as Cases Soar
description: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.
